sections.heading: Wish Fulfillment, Healing and Spiritual Training
sections.text:
Freud thought dreams were wish fulfillment fantasies, Jung saw them as healing to imbalanced psyches, and Joseph Campbell saw myths as spiritual training. The Arthurian romances are so successful because on one level they're wish fulfillment, on another they are healing to an imbalanced collective psyche that devalued the feminine, and on another level, they offer tremendous spiritual training. What a good storyteller knows is that the fantasy is exactly what seduces us into a plot that brings change. It is exactly the wish fulfillments that are, on the surface, the most seductive. Then, once we are pulled into the dream, we can be worked, transformed and changed by the efforts of a storyteller.

Stories that are true are successful. We're drawn to stories that resonate. We don't always know what they're resonating with, and the truth they represent might not be literal or moral. In the case of Arthur, it resonates with its audience on countless levels. True romantic fantasies and true romantic nightmares, resonant visions of both moral righteousness and moral failure.

sections.heading: Europe's Cauldron of Stories
sections.text:
Common myths support common identities, and part of why the Arthurian material spread across Europe is because it resonated with so many Europeans. Its ability to do so came from its ability to reflect so much myth and history -- Classical, Christian, Celtic and Caucasian myths, memories, magic and crusades. With a French Lancelot and a German Parzival, the story created sharable narratives and identities. If King Arthur is the best known Brit in the world, it's because he's the most mixed Brit there's ever been.

The Mayan throne was a mat on which the culture's myth was woven, and into this myth was woven the entirety of their culture. This is a perfect metaphor for the Arthurian throne. His myth is one that weaves together the threads of Europe. We can work to pick apart its sources, but its successful resonance with so many people depends on the successful blending of so many identities. Tolkien's point about Arthur is that storytellers draw from what he called a Cauldron of Stories -- a poetic expression of the imagination. Do our dreams not mix life with legend? Myths are no different.

sections.heading: The Hypermasculine Quest for the Feminine
sections.text:
Jung saw dreams as snapshots of the psyche that represent both its imbalance and its internal efforts to heal. What we see in the Arthurian stories is a representation of a hypermasculine, hyperchristian reality trying to heal its rift with femininity. On one hand this looks like Guinevere's feminine disruption of a hypermasculine order, and on another, we see the Grail quest as a quest for the feminine.

The Arthurian consciousness is expressed as both repressing the feminine and in quest for it. Morgana represents the repressed feminine vitality. The wasteland of Arthurian legend represents the wasteland we get when we repress feminine vitality. The story of Guinevere represents the shadow disruption of the feminine when it's repressed. And the Grail quest represents our recognition that the splitting off and repression of feminine consciousness has created a wasteland that can only be redeemed by integrating what we've split off. The story of Camelot is the story of Eden recast as a narrative with which Europeans can identify. On another level, it's the story of anyone whose household has been destroyed by infidelity.

sections.heading: Arthur, Hercules and the Journey of the Sun
sections.text:
Arthur looks a lot like Hercules. In the folklore, his shield can become a boat, which reminds us of the cupboat Hercules takes to the Hesperides, an island of golden apples. Arthur also goes to an island of golden apples. And though both narratives associate the cup and a woman with life everlasting, the most obvious similarity of these culture-defining heroes is their origin story. Both were conceived by a father who pretended to be their mother's husband.

We follow Arthur from his birth to his rise, his fall, and all the way to his death and removal to Avalon, the island of golden apples. This is an ending at the sunset, a journey of the sun, just like the riddle of the Sphinx in the story of Oedipus. Arthur's rise and arrival is like the birth and arrival of the sun, and his rise to prominence is like the sun's rise to noon. The journey of the king and the journey of the sun are deeply associated with one another. They were in medieval Europe, and they were also associated with Christ, Horus, Osiris and so many other figures.

sections.heading: The Printing Press and the Power of New Media
sections.text:
King Arthur represents the consolidation of European and pagan mythologies, and the Morte d'Arthur represents the consolidation of all those Arthurian pieces. This happened at the exact same time the printing press came online, creating a gargantuan phenomenon. Not only did it resonate with the entirety of Europe in deep and profound ways, it was also distributable. Malory's Morte d'Arthur was one of the first major texts to be published with the printing press. Every time there's a new medium, every time there's a new level of distribution, there is a new level of phenomenon.

From Nennius to the World Wars, Arthur's defense of England tends to be renewed every time it needs defenders. These stories don't just model ideals of the state and its status quo, they also point to a path of individual development from and beyond the state. While Arthur redefines the standard of governance as motivated by fairness and equality, the quest for the Grail is spiritual, mystical, philosophical and profound. There's a reason why Wagner's Parsifal was an adaptation of his earlier interpretation of Siddhartha's quest for enlightenment.

king-arthur.overview: The Arthurian romances are the most successful state myth of the most recent global empire — and also one of history's most profound examples of spiritual training embedded in wish fulfillment. Beneath the fantasy of an ideal kingdom lies a hypermasculine, hyperchristian psyche in quest for the feminine it has split off. The story resonates because it weaves together the threads of an entire continent — Classical, Celtic, Christian and Caucasian — and because its underlying pattern, the journey of the sun, is older than any single culture it absorbed.

sections.heading: A Repository for the Unproven
sections.text:
The Bermuda Triangle is alive today as an active part of our collective imagination. Based on the role it plays, it has become a repository for virtually every unproven but not disproven possibility -- from aliens to mystical energy and sea monsters, rare natural phenomena, you name it. The Bermuda Triangle isn't just a repository for all kinds of myths and phenomena, it's also one of the key places they all converge. Atlantis, underwater archaeology, psychic powers, UFOs, military mysteries -- all of these threads become fabric in the mythic triangle.

The oldest kings were of fishing ports, and wild stories about the sea are as old as boats. You might say there's always been a Bermuda Triangle -- a place over there beyond the known and observed, where all the craziest stuff you ever heard of happens. From Greek mythological sea monsters to mysterious phenomenon in the Bermuda Triangle, this is just an updated incarnation of the same old story.

sections.heading: Rogue Waves and Convergent Myths
sections.text:
One of the theories of what goes on in the Bermuda Triangle involves rogue waves, which, while literally compelling, make even better metaphors. The Bermuda Triangle is where all the little disturbances in our imagination add up to something huge. Some of these disturbances may be statistical, some psychological projections, some weird but natural, and under this cover, who knows, maybe there's some stuff we won't understand without expanding our worldviews.

The term rogue wave is a misnomer -- they aren't the most rogue of waves, they're the most convergent. Their harmonic or constructive interference is what makes them huge. A myth is like a rogue wave born of countless small ideas that converge in the fluid medium of our imaginations. Charles Berlitz wrote at the convergence of three great myths -- Atlantis, the Bermuda Triangle and Aliens. Fact or fiction, this weaving of threads has created the fabric of what we now think of as the Bermuda Triangle.

sections.heading: Ancient Perils in Modern Dress
sections.text:
Skylla and Charybdis seem to be personified versions of true perils -- a tight strait, dangerous rocks and even maelstroms. The Skylla and Charybdis of the Bermuda Triangle are the Blue Hole vortexes and limestone breakers, dangerous rocks that can be invisible on calm days. As with Charybdis, locals in the Bahamas personify the ship-destroying vortices as monsters. The most famous is called Lusca, whose breath creates the maelstrom.

One of the recurring themes -- from the Bermuda Triangle to the Devil's Sea -- is that many of the ships are carrying ore. Another theme is that electric or magnetic instruments have failed or been affected. The fact that humanity's relationship with electromagnetism and radio waves is relatively new means that we are still integrating it into both our understanding and our imaginations. These stories play with both -- sometimes there are phenomena we hardly understand, and in some cases the Bermuda Triangle is serving as a place for our imagination to model possibilities.

sections.heading: Why We Need the Mystery
sections.text:
We don't want to believe in a world without miracles, which for most of us, conscious or not, means living in a world without soul, free will, divine presence or potentially even meaning. It's not just about the things that can happen there, it's that those are the places they seem most likely to happen, and if they can't happen there, they can't happen anywhere.

There is a lot of unknown territory in our psyche -- we need a place in the world to project our inner unknown. The Bermuda Triangle has become one of these places. The Bermuda Triangle doesn't stand out statistically as much as it stands out in our imaginations. If you want to believe everything is explainable, that's the myth you'll project onto the lost ships. If you want to believe in aliens or Atlantis, then that's the myth you'll project. So long as traumatic events continue to happen and ships keep disappearing, we're going to keep seeing all of our myths.

bermuda-triangle.overview: The Bermuda Triangle is where all the little disturbances in our imagination converge into something huge — a modern incarnation of the ancient place beyond the known where the wildest stories happen. From Greek sea monsters to military mysteries, it functions less as a geographic anomaly than as a repository for every unproven but not disproven possibility. The myth persists not because the statistics support it, but because we need a place in the world onto which we can project our inner unknown.

sections.heading: The Endless Incarnations of the Grail
sections.text:
The Grail myths aren't consistent with one another. One version is that Joseph of Arimathea hosted the last supper, caught Jesus' blood in its cup, then carried it to Glastonbury. Another version is that Peter carried it from Israel to Rome and sent it to Spain for safety. Another is that the Templars found or were given the Grail upon their arrival in Jerusalem. Meanwhile, the conflation of the Grail from Arthurian legend with the Holy Cup was a later development. Some stories say the Grail was Cathar treasure or a vessel used during pagan rites transformed for Christianity. Several scholars associate it with earlier images like the Classical cup of Hebe or Celtic Cauldron of Dagda. Then there are the arguments that it isn't a grail at all, it's a stone -- the philosopher's stone -- which turns the grail into a symbol for enlightenment.

In Inception, Nolan points out that if you put a safe in a dream, the dreamer will put what's precious in that safe. The Grail works in the same way -- whatever is most precious to us, that's what we see in the Grail. We're obsessed with the Grail because we see our obsessions in that vessel, and we find real wisdom on the quest.

sections.heading: The Inner Quest for the Divine
sections.text:
Crusades are pilgrimages, which are journeys to god. When the crusaders got to Jerusalem, the place where God was supposed to be, and when the Templars took over the temple, I think they didn't find him, and I think they kept looking -- under the temple and across the world. Everyone wants the Grail for different reasons, but one of them was a sincere existential need to find god, to find divine union. This is the same pursuit that drove alchemists towards the philosopher's stone. The outer journey is but a projection of the inner quest.

The deeper and wider you go, the more you come to recognize that the core common denominator is love -- love heals mind, body and soul as well as crops and even belligerence. Love is the elixir we drink, it's the gate we walk through to find union with self, with cosmos, and even with the divine. In many ways, the Grail stories are in opposition to the testosterone-colored violence and persecution of their day. Parzival climaxes when Fierfitz and Parzival stop fighting. When you stand under the stone at Roslyn where they say you can see the Grail, you've got to realize the Grail is you, and your capacity to heal, create, unify and find wisdom -- through love.

sections.heading: Powers of Creation and Renewal
sections.text:
The Grail is like a condensed conduit for the powers of creation. This energy comes with love and wisdom, it heals individuals and whole lands, brings life, restores sanity, delivers food, is endlessly full of wine and can unite the bearer with god. As a cornucopia, the Grail represents the endless refilling of both Earth and Mother with offspring and new life. The way wine endlessly refills the Grail can be seen in the monthly refilling of the maternal vessel with the life-giving blood of menstruation.

Geoffrey of Monmouth, who wrote the first great work about Arthur, didn't write about the Grail. In the Vita Merlini, however, he wrote about apples that made knights go mad and an elixir that restored their clarity. Perhaps the greatest power of the Grail myths was the way they helped heal Crusade-induced trauma. These are stories that follow the arc of a closed heart that opens and a wasteland that's redeemed -- of warriors who stop fighting and lovers who start loving.

sections.heading: Pagan Roots and Christian Vessels
sections.text:
The most important ritual in Christianity is the Mass, which centers around the cup of wine providing a path to spiritual immortality -- like the Holy Grail. Whether or not there's a literal link, to our imagination, these holy vessels are resonant, mimetic and easily conflatable. One of the popular theories of the Grail is that the tradition emerges from the relationship of Christianity with more ancient mystery religions throughout the Mediterranean. These traditions typically revolve around some kind of death, resurrection and immortality deity, like Dionysus, Mithras, Attis, Adonis, Persephone, Osiris, Inanna.

In the oldest real megamyth we have, Inanna is brought back from death on a cross with bread and elixir of life contained within the lunar thumbnail. Dionysus is the god of wine, with which we toast the living. Blood, elixirs and vessels are central to many of these cults. So as Christianity displaced the pagan religion, it is believed that many of these mystery traditions came to assimilate the myth in their own ways. Could these cults have contributed to Grail legends? Most of these traditions were wiped out by crusades and inquisitions, and myths tend to get written down when things are ending. Could some of these cults have avoided complete annihilation? This is one of the places where the bottom drops out into mystery.

sections.heading: The Grail as Relic and Connection
sections.text:
A relic is a connection to a source -- to the Buddha, to Mohammad, to Christ -- and that connection is valuable because of their connection with the divine. The Grail is the ultimate relic. Not only is it an object that connects with someone connected with the divine, this is seen as the actual object that makes the connection. The Grail is the source of wine-blood that delivers salvation and immortality. It is the ultimate relic that offers an ultimate connection with the divine.

The very essence of the Christian religion depends on its literal truth -- that Jesus was real and the son of God. Yet it was the Muslims who had Mohammad's sword and other real relics. This is why some believe that the European interest in relics was in response to their collision with Islam. Core to the Christian tradition is the notion that something perfectly symbolic -- like Christ -- could also be very real. We have older cups that were less significant to fewer people, so if Jesus was a historical figure, which is the consensus among academics, then the literal possibility is entirely plausible.

holy-grail.overview: The Grail works like Nolan's safe in Inception — whatever is most precious to us, that is what we see in the vessel. Its endless incarnations, from Celtic cauldron to philosopher's stone to the blood of Christ, reflect not confusion but the nature of the symbol itself. The Grail is not one thing. It is a vessel, a stone, a lineage, a technology, and a question — and the question it asks is whether the seeker can hold all of these dimensions at once without reducing them to a single answer.

sections.heading: The Capitalist Myth Before Capitalism
sections.text:
Encoded in this mythic predecessor of the capitalist ideal, we get an early glimpse of its shadow. In the story of El Dorado, we see the disregard of others and sacredness for the purpose of wealth. The pursuit of personal fortune, especially in the West, is a living myth. It's a capitalist myth. Before El Dorado, great quests were for truth and holy objects. The story of El Dorado, however, reduced treasure to wealth.

As Tolkien pointed out, gold gives us what he called dragon sickness, a kind of greed and belligerence that comes to disregard the wellbeing of others. Conquistadors had this sickness. The confusion of El Dorado for a person, city, and civilization is itself telling. In great stories you often see an individual that personifies the health and well-being of a land. If what's holy is money, your pilgrimage is to a wellspring of wealth. And this isn't just to degrade the quest to something secular -- from within their mindset, the pursuit of gold was existentially meaningful.

sections.heading: The Golden Road of the Sun
sections.text:
Heroic conquistadors journeyed across the western ocean to western lands for golden treasure, like Hercules, who crossed the western ocean for golden apples, and Coyote, who swam to the Channel Islands for a golden flower. This is a recurring motif -- the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow, only the rainbow would be better understood as the yellow brick road or the yellow arrows that point the way from anywhere in Europe to its westernmost point in Santiago. The golden road is the road of the sun, which sets in the west, where, culture after culture, imagines treasure.

All across Europe, golden arrows lead to Santiago. Follow these arrows. And when you reach what you thought was the end of your pilgrimage, follow the sun across the sea, to America, where the streets are paved in gold. Then follow these yellow brick roads until you reach the end of the rainbow. And there, where sun sets on the shoulders of Atlas, you'll find the promised land, El Dorado.

sections.heading: El Dorado Was a Man, Not a City
sections.text:
El Dorado was a man who covered himself from head to toe in gold -- an unforgettable sight that spread through the South American imagination, but by the time it got to the Spanish, El Dorado was a city of gold. The king is the master of all of the gold and all of that power and light and vitality from which existence comes. The health of the king is associated with the health of the land. The sun going down into the water is symbolized by the golden objects going down into the water. These are common rituals for kings -- the reason Arthur's sword must go back into the water upon his death, a motif ancient for Indo-Europeans.

The Muisca covered the new king with gold dust, crowns, bracelets and precious stones in a kind of coronation ceremony. This treasure was taken on a raft to the middle of Lake Guatavita, where the gold was thrown into the murky depths as an offering to the gods. Despite numerous attempts to fish the gold and jewels from the bottom, few clues to the treasure were found. Here is where El Dorado becomes a myth.

sections.heading: A Hero's Journey of Ego Death
sections.text:
The road to El Dorado is a classic hero's journey. You leave from home as a representative of your culture's status quo, depart for some great adventure crossing some great ocean to some foreign land where everything is completely different. At first you are overwhelmed, but then you learn how things work. But then you fail to find what you thought you would find, which shatters the ego. Disillusionment should set in. And having not gotten what you wanted, you should find what you really need. Or if you are the bad guy in the story, you keep wanting it anyway, at the expense of lives, love, care, and any consideration for others.

Unfortunately, the hero's journey is a journey highlighted by disillusionment and ego death. In the case of the conquistadors, those who went in search for El Dorado all failed, and they all suffered that loss. Along the way, great damage was done. Whatever role the conquistador played, the completion of the journey would be their return home, to deliver whatever they found -- gold or wisdom -- as the new person they'd become. No conquistador returned from the Americas the same person who left.

el-dorado.overview: El Dorado is the capitalist myth before capitalism — the moment when great quests shifted from truth and holy objects to the pursuit of wealth itself. The golden road is the road of the sun, and the conquistadors who followed it west were walking a path as old as Hercules crossing the ocean for golden apples. But the hero's journey demands disillusionment and ego death, and every conquistador who searched for El Dorado failed, suffered that loss, and returned home a different person.

sections.heading: The Seat of God on Earth
sections.text:
Like the seat of Apollo at Delphi, the Ark is God's throne on earth -- the seat of god, like the sunboat of Osiris or the cupboat of Helios. And like these solar seats, the golden Ark is a guiding light that leads souls to life beyond their world. As the Ark leads Jews to the Holy Land, the sunboat of Osiris leads souls to a life after death. As the star led to Jesus, the Ark led to Israel. These guiding lights presented hope -- hope for change, hope for a new day. And whether it comes from Christ, Prometheus or Moses, hope is the light, brought from heaven to earth.

The Ark also looks and sounds a lot like Aker, the seat of Osiris in the innermost chamber of the Egyptian underworld -- the scene where the first divine spark comes into its vessel. This seat is flanked by two chimera and two birds, which together look like Cherubim. Like the sun rising from night, the Ark rose from Egypt and the desert to bring hope and promise a new day.

sections.heading: The Power of Creation and Destruction
sections.text:
The Big Bang is only the most recent myth about some point from which creation came. And for the Jews, this point was in the dead center of their temple, before the Ark -- the seat of the creator at the seat of creation. Lightning, meteors, plagues and the sun are but derivations of its true power, which is all power -- a power not meant for human wants. In the Jewish imagination, creation was from the center, for which reason the tree of Eden, the cross, and the temple were described as in this center. Over the exact center was the foundation stone of our reality, on which was written the name of God.

Uzzah was immediately struck dead when he touched the Ark, as though smitten by lightning for his disobedience. The Ark is like the forbidden fruit in Pandora's box. Those who disobey god -- those who look in the box or pursue its knowledge -- are punished. Until the scientific discovery of electricity, until Ben Franklin brought lightning down to earth on the string of a kite, lightning was heavenly, and its presence on earth would have been seen as either miraculous or magical.

sections.heading: Where Myth Meets Memory
sections.text:
The Ark is at the exact precipice between myth and memory when scholars think priests started writing down stories -- this was in response to the Babylonian invasion and exile, which compromised a living, oral tradition. The Ark is said to have been in the possession of the Jews right up until the time they started emphasizing the written tradition. It becomes myth when, according to Maccabees, it was taken to a cave in Jordan to be hidden from the invading Babylonians. Like the Grail, the Ark enters and leaves history, like a metaphor for a god who spoke to us and stopped.

Exile from Eden and losing the Ark are stories about separation from home and god. Though they both carry incredibly ancient material, the focus on writing them down seems to have been in response to the Temple's destruction and the Babylonian exile. Whether or not the story of the Ark is historically true, it expresses true historic experience.

sections.heading: A Traveling God for a Traveling People
sections.text:
Gods are associated with locations, but when you're leaving to go somewhere new, God would have to be taken with you. It's not just that the Ark serves as a seat for God, it also served as a transport. When Gilgamesh asks for the secret of eternal life, the clue is that immortality has only been attained by the one who turned his house into a boat, into an ark. And so the Ark of the Covenant is not just the seat of god on earth, it's a moving throne. It is only because the Ark can travel that, according to legend, it has survived. The same can be said of Judaism itself.

When Semites moved to Egypt they began worshiping Egyptian gods, in part because deities were understood to be local. But when the Semites leave Egypt with Moses, their god is presented as having a home that moves -- he is a traveling god. From the nomadic tent in which it lived to the churches still shaped like upside-down arks, the Abrahamic home of God is meant to evoke this traveling quality, which seems to be integral to its dispersion and global success.

We still want what the Ark can give -- knowledge of god and a connection with the divine. The human condition established by Adam and Prometheus is one of estrangement and separation. Like Adam, we experience separation as loneliness. Our isolation is a source of existential dread. And this dread sets up a desire for union, for oneness or wholeness, and this motivation is behind our love for stories about union, which tend to be journeys to some divine source.

ark-of-the-covenant.overview: The Ark sits at the exact precipice between myth and memory — the moment when priests began writing down stories in response to the Babylonian exile, preserving a living tradition that was slipping away. Like the golden sunboat of Osiris, it is a guiding light and a traveling throne for a traveling god. The Ark enters and leaves history like a metaphor for a god who spoke to us and stopped, and the desire to recover it is inseparable from the desire for divine union that defines the human condition.

sections.heading: The Mythologization of History
sections.text:
The Nibelung shows the mythic mixing of history with divine narratives in a way that gives a sense of how this could have been happening behind more ancient myths. Arthur gives us another great example, as a historical figure who became a magnet for mythic material. Arthur's defense of Britain, the Iliad, and Genesis concern the fall of regional powers in the context of collapsing world orders. The same can be said of the Nibelung, which is about the fall of the Burgundians, contingent with the fall of Rome. Attila, the Burgundian nemesis, was the reaper of Rome.

In the Nibelung, history, myth and metallurgy align around core patterns capable of reflecting more than just historical, mythic or metallurgical meaning. For example, the single weakness of quenched steel becomes the single weakness of a hero's personality becomes the mythic downfall of a historic culture. The pattern of the single weakness then sustains the projection of whatever flaw concerns its audience. Myth is like nuclear fusion -- it requires the combination of multiple cores to create something new.

sections.heading: Men of Steel
sections.text:
The strength of Siegfried's blade comes from plunging it in blood, and his single weakness is the leaf that covered him when he bathed. These details pertain to the tempering of iron, which is strengthened by dipping it in cool water but is weak where held in the process. This is clarified by a myth in the Caucasus, where the man of steel is created in the smithy and is described as steel, only vulnerable where held when dipped. In this story, it's on the surface, and it shows us what's really going on with Siegfried, Achilles and Jason.

For ages, metallurgy and religion focused on purification. The discovery of steel, however, was the discovery of the strongest, most immortal of metals that came with a bit of corruption. This is what we see in the earliest personifications of men of steel -- not only are they stronger and more invincible than anyone else, they also corrupt the laws of god. The single weakness of Achilles becomes the place on the body where he sacrilegiously injures Hektor. This small corruption of the strongest hero is a mythopoetic expression of steel itself, which is stronger as a result of its corruption -- carbon. Personified, this is the anti-hero.

sections.heading: Swords, Treasures and the Dragon's Gold
sections.text:
Swords are incredible symbols. The first long swords were made of iron, and the first iron was made of meteorites -- so the first sword is a meteor sword, which colors its symbol forever. In that the sword is made of a light from heaven, it's often associated with the divine right of rule. In that the sword is a death bringer made of a fallen light, the fiery sword can represent the fall. The word science comes from a root word that means to cut or divide, highlighting the notion of knowledge as discerning.

So long as there's treasure in the imagination there will be treasure in myth. As long as we treasure something, even if it's something immaterial like love, it will be symbolized as real treasure. Because we so frequently see treasure corrupt the people who pursue it, we end up with cautionary tales -- from Tolkien's notion of Dragon Sickness to the Ballad of Buster Scruggs. Insofar as wealth is power and power corrupts, wealth corrupts.

sections.heading: The Dream Life of a Culture
sections.text:
Freud thought dreams were driven by wish fulfillment. Jung thought they were part of psychological homeostasis, which seeks balance and wholeness. For him, dreams provide compensatory content that counterbalances daily experience. Myths and dreams draw us in with the promise of wish fulfillment and then drag us through a process of development. Joseph Campbell saw myths as spiritual training -- we get the training from the heroes, who we emulate, and also in the morality of the authorship, which isn't always aligned with the protagonists.

From Jung's point of view, the defeat of the dragon was the defeat of the inner tyrant that limited the flow of life's forces. When Siegfried hears the birds and the bees after tasting the blood of the dragon, it's like an inversion of the Eden myth, where the ability to speak with animals is lost as a result of eating the fruit. Psychologically, the defeat of one's inner tyrant or ego permits the restoration of one's relationship with emotion and intuition. Sufi mystics believe we should clean the mirrors of our heart -- empty ourselves of ego so that something greater can come through and be heard.

nibelung.overview: In the Nibelung, history, myth and metallurgy align around core patterns capable of reflecting more than just one domain of meaning. The single weakness of quenched steel becomes the single weakness of a hero's personality becomes the mythic downfall of a historic culture. This is myth as nuclear fusion — requiring the combination of multiple cores to create something new. Beneath the epic of Siegfried lies one of the clearest examples of how real history becomes layered with divine narratives, in a way that reveals how this process has been working behind more ancient myths for millennia.

sections.heading: Stealing Fire from the Gods
sections.text:
Stealing from the rich to give to the poor is like stealing fire from the gods to give to humans, and what both stories are really about is the restoration of vitality and freedom that's been oppressed by tyranny, order and taxation. Robin robs from the rich and gives to the poor. Prometheus steals fire from the gods to give to humans -- humans Zeus would have taxed to death. This is the timeless story of a trickster-led rebellion against the oppression of vitality by the life-sucking grip of a tyrant's laws.

On the deepest level, this is the story of a trickster disrupting order to free stifled vitality. So though Robin is healing a kingdom, he looks a lot like the green fertility figures who restore nature. This is a story of freedom versus order, rebellion versus tyranny.

sections.heading: The Prototype for Revolution
sections.text:
Hunting of forbidden game with a bow is an introduction shared by Robin Hood and Katniss, who can tell us a lot about him. Not only do they both lead rebellions against a scheme of taxation, but in the case of the Hunger Games, the taxation is human life, which is a more direct stand-in for human vitality. Robin Hood is the prototype for the story of the American Revolution, and by extension, the American Dream. Like the American Revolution, Robin Hood leads a rebellion on behalf of the overtaxed against a tyrannical monarch of England. Both result in a just government, and where Robin Hood has become conflated with the Magna Carta's origin story, the American Revolution gave birth to modern democracy.

V for Vendetta is a favorite Robin Hood character. Without the bow, we see the same lighthearted romantic revolutionary fighting back against an English tyrant. This is a mythic structure we remember from Prometheus and the birth of Athenian democracy.

sections.heading: The Cauldron of Outlaws
sections.text:
There have been and there will continue to be real Robin Hoods. On one hand, there are very real historic figures who appear in the earliest records of his myth, and on the other, historic people will continue to be integrated. Tolkien pushed back against scholars attempting to reduce Arthur to a single historic figure by suggesting that a good storyteller draws from a cauldron of stories -- an undifferentiated mixture of sources. It's less about making sense of what specific source ended up in which specific story and more about what's in the soup and how it's served.

We keep throwing more and more Robin Hoods in the soup, but we keep selecting around the same criteria. From history to folklore, we're looking for better and better details to tell the story that wants to be told. And the story that wants to be told is one of a pure-hearted rebel against a hard-hearted king -- the vitality of a trickster versus the vampirism of a tyrant. While the story has gotten further from any single historic origin, it's gotten closer and closer to its archetypal truth.

sections.heading: The Moon Against the Sun
sections.text:
When the law is not just, outlaws become heroes. When laws oppress, from literal slavery to vampiric taxation, to break that law becomes heroic. Robin Hood does two things characteristic of all true heroes: not only does he bring truth and fairness to the world, he does so at extreme risk against a greater force. His opposition to tyranny is no less than a David and Goliath matchup between an individual and the power of the state.

The conflict of sun and moon is a conflict defined by the sun's tyrannical dominance and the moon's mysterious ways. Where the solar king is linear, power-driven and direct, Robin is associated with music, wine, romance and the forest. He takes no offense when losing a fight to Little John as a king would. What we're seeing is a counterbalance to an overly solar, masculine and power-driven psyche with the levity of Robin's trickster heart, with the dark mystery of the forest and an understanding of those people oppressed towards the darker spaces.

robin-hood.overview: Stealing from the rich to give to the poor is like stealing fire from the gods to give to humans — both stories are about the restoration of vitality oppressed by tyranny. Robin Hood is the prototype for the story of revolution, from the Magna Carta to the American Dream to V for Vendetta. Where the solar king is linear, power-driven and direct, Robin is the moon — associated with music, wine, romance and the mystery of the forest. The conflict of sun and moon, order and freedom, is as timeless as the myth itself.

sections.heading: Feminine Ferocity Focused
sections.text:
Attila's army was defined by the advantages of archers on horseback, and there's nothing that could stop a woman from learning this skill. A group of women on horseback with bows would be devastatingly dangerous on any ancient battlefield. Diana or Artemis, like the Amazons, wields the bow. The bow represents aiming focus. Where the Dionysian Maenads enact the destructive force of feminine fury, their scariest quality is unthinking belligerence. Athena bears the Gorgon on her shield to display her inner mastery of this feminine fury, and Artemis bears a bow to demonstrate the focus of this feminine ferocity into a single penetrating dart.

Some Amazons bear the image of the Gorgon on their shield -- like Athena. This represents the warrior woman's ability to harness her inner Gorgon, which is a nightmarish interpretation of feminine vitality. As with male berserker warriors like Hercules and Ajax, those woman warriors who can channel their inner rage into a disciplined fighting style are the most fearsome of all. This is the same reason we see the Gorgon on the shield of Zeus, whose Olympian order subdued the Titanic -- it represents the ability to harness that raw part of ourselves with inner discipline and intellect.

sections.heading: Shadows of Athenian Wives
sections.text:
It's not only that women were oppressed in ancient Greece, it's that they saw femininity as something to be oppressed. From Pandora to Eve, there's an association of mother with matter. In Latin, they share the same word -- Mater. From Christianity to the philosophy of Socrates, there is a belief that matter and embodiment is a prison that corrupts consciousness. This hasn't just led to the repression of qualities identified as feminine, it's led to the objectification and oppression of real women. The subduing of bodily sin has been indistinguishable from the suppressing of females and femininity.

Amazons might be seen as perfect shadows for ancient Athenian wives, who did not govern or fight. In contrast with the highly oppressed lifestyles of ancient Greek wives, their images of Athena and Artemis were warriors. In fairytales we have the contrast between wicked witches and fairy godmothers, representing two sides of feminine potential. Where the frenzy of a Maenad represents unbound instinct, the discipline of Amazon archers represents the potential to focus that destructive potency into a single aimed shot.

sections.heading: A Memory of Mating Rituals
sections.text:
There's no doubt that Amazons served as wonder women for ancient Greek men, whose heroes sought them as brides. Heroes and Amazons fall in love with one another on the battlefield once one has bested the other in a very close struggle. On one level this might be a memory of a very real mating ritual in which Indo-European war bands set out in search of women. On another level, lovers continue to look for their match, and love is never free of power. The fight between male and female warriors becomes a poetic expression of love and lust.

Women were treated so unequally in ancient Athens that a peer-to-peer relationship was unthinkable enough for men to only know peer-to-peer romance as existing between men. In a society like that, the male wish for a peer might look like a fantasy tale in which warrior women were found on an adventure. Recent discoveries have shown that many ancient Amazonian names are Abkhazian, Ubek and Ossetian. To this day, these people tell stories of Narts, and among these Narts is a figure named Amazan, a woman warrior who leads a band of women who live in the forest.

sections.heading: From the Amazons to Wonder Woman
sections.text:
Amazon myths are a conglomeration of several things. They represent a memory of what may have been a more matriarchal period in human history. Their battles with men may capture memories of an ancient mating ritual. They are certainly shadow figures for oppressed Athenian wives and fantasy figures for Athenian men. Beneath all of this, they may be a real historical group of fighting women that doesn't deserve but might actually appreciate their emergence as poetic representatives of repressed ferocity and feminine focus.

Female action heroes are not masculinized women -- women can fight, with their bodies and minds, which finds expression in the poetic stories of Diana and the Amazons. When women fight, they use feminine power, related to their sexuality as much as their motherhood. And when women fight, it tends to be for feminine motivations, from exacting revenge on the unjust treatment of women to the defense of their nests. William Marston was a psychologist and writer who believed in love and women at a time defined by men at war. In one of the most meaningful scenes in recent memory, we see Diana emerge from the trenches to stare down the full fury of the Nazi army, and in that moment we see the rising of repressed feminine vitality against the very worst of our world's hypermasculine toxicity.

amazons.overview: The Amazons are simultaneously a memory of what may have been a more matriarchal past, shadow figures for oppressed Athenian wives, and fantasy figures for men who could only imagine peer-to-peer romance in the form of warrior women found on an adventure. Beneath these layers, they may represent a real historical group of fighting women — archers on horseback whose focused ferocity, from Diana to Wonder Woman, continues to rise against the very worst of hypermasculine toxicity.

sections.heading: Civilizations Before the Flood
sections.text:
Atlantis is fascinating because of the way it relates to the bigger picture of prehistoric civilizations and the way it ties into world history. It really has to do with ancient seafaring cultures, which may have been more evolved than their on-land counterparts. The oldest cities were fishing cities. Atlantis could be seen as a culture from a mythological time before the flood, vanished from a greater event.

There are a lot of cultures who tell stories like Atlantis. In the same way Atlantis vanished, so did Eden in the Bible and the Sumerian Eden, Dilmun, which was a seafaring culture like the Atlanteans. Thera was also lost to the sea. If there was an early civilization that was flooded, then the coastal cities would have been lost like Atlantis. It is likely that the myth of Atlantis was inspired by several real and mythical examples.

sections.heading: The Strait Where Empires Grow
sections.text:
Atlantis could be very real -- in fact, multiple Atlantises could be real. It could even be that Plato was combining several. Plato locates Atlantis where the Mediterranean opens into the Atlantic. Throughout history, cities have become very powerful and rich controlling such straits. The most famous examples would be Troy and Constantinople. Troy and Constantinople got wildly rich by controlling the strait between the Mediterranean and Black Sea. It's hard to imagine that a culture wouldn't have grown up and gotten rich where the Mediterranean and Atlantic connect, especially when you consider how much trade was going on between the North Atlantic and the Mediterranean.

The fall of the Minoans started just after the eruption of Thera and continued until just after the fall of Troy. It's possible that the Minoans participated in a larger alliance of seafaring cultures that included a significant port city in the Atlantic, and it's possible a series of natural and human disasters led to the gradual decline of that network. From my point of view, the Minoans are not the Atlanteans, but given a few of Plato's descriptions, it seems likely that they influenced his story.

sections.heading: A Blank Screen for Projection
sections.text:
The search for Atlantis is like a quest for the Grail -- a myth unto itself. From Disney to Hasbro, DC and Marvel, stories of the search for Atlantis or other underwater civilizations are common. There are a lot of supernatural theories, and you've got to locate them somewhere. The Atlantean mystery creates a blank screen for endless projection. The idea of advanced technology opens into the alien myth, as does their existence beneath the water, which would provide the atmospheric pressure required for aliens on bigger planets. So there's enough plausibility and mystery mixed together to sustain almost anything.

Atlantis is a metaphor for many things. It depends on who's looking at it. If you want to see your belief that a culture was perfect before its fall, or want to see a Sodom and Gomorrah story, it's in there as well. Atlantis metaphorically represents the possibility of a fall following hubris, for an individual or a collective. It's a kind of end-of-the-world story at the beginning, which can be taken as a metaphor for the cycles of time.

atlantis.overview: Atlantis is fascinating because of the way it ties into the bigger picture of prehistoric civilizations and what came before the flood. It could be very real — multiple Atlantises could be real — positioned where the Mediterranean opens to the Atlantic, the kind of strait where empires have always grown rich. But its most enduring power is as a blank screen for projection: whatever you want to believe about lost civilizations, advanced technology, or the hubris that precedes a fall, Atlantis will hold it.

sections.heading: Energy Beings and Shape Shifters
sections.text:
When you look dead on at a serpent, it's a point. When you pull it tight, it's a line, but it can also be a wave, circle, or any other shape. Serpents and the dragons with which they're associated are shape shifters, but shapes aren't just in our world, they're in our minds. The mastery of form represented by the serpent isn't just a mastery of the world and its patterns, it's a capacity to understand how the patterns in our world relate to the patterns in our consciousness.

The dragon is energy that takes form, from rivers and flowing lava to chakras and rainbows. When we see serpent after serpent with mother after mother, we see example after example of a certain philosophy -- that we are not just born from our mothers, we are also like dragons, beings of energy taking form. Everything is -- all matter is energy, taking form. The Buddha teaches us that a flower is not earth, water, light or seed -- it's what happens when they take form together.

sections.heading: Rivers, Storms and the Demonization of Vitality
sections.text:
Our understanding of the dragon came from rivers -- the Nile and Yellow River were explicitly dragons for the first Chinese and Egyptian civilizations. Dragons govern everything like rivers govern the life within them. Conquerors demonize their enemies, so when rivers were conquered, the dragons that represented them became seen as demons. Because China's river valley civilizations were never conquered by outsiders, they still valorize their dragons.

However, the other great river civilizations were defeated in the Iron Age, by greater weapons. As the river valleys were subdued, stories emerged of dragons defeated by heroes. The conquering emperors of China took a different approach -- they claimed to be the dragons and usurped their icons. The same can be said of Uther Pendragon, father of Arthur, who, by stealing the dragon's image, conflated it with tyranny. The dragon itself is not a tyrant. It is the flowing river, the flowing lava, the rainbow of freedom. Tyranny is when the river is conquered, when the mountain becomes a symbol of hoarding, and the rainbow becomes a mere call for gold.

sections.heading: Maiden and Serpent, Slayer and the Slain
sections.text:
The maiden and serpent are consorts throughout world mythology. From Eden to Tonga, the serpent is experienced as a seducer, which reveals the obvious association of the serpent with the male organ. When damsels are distressed by the dragon, femininity is distressed by the masculine. Her symbolic rescue and union with the hero is a balance-restoring myth. When this story occurs as the dream of a single dreamer, the dreamer is freeing his own femininity from his own masculine imbalance.

To slay a dragon is to vanquish what they represent. Sometimes we see them as hoarders, sometimes as tyrants, but they are also energy beings with magic and knowledge. To kill a dragon is often presented as the killing of fantasy, of magic, and life force itself. In the story of St. George we see the wishful fantasy of evil defeated and the devil subdued, which soothed a very scared and traumatized medieval soul. The defeat of the devil is also the defeat of paganism and non-Christian religions, and the dragon represents the ultimate source of non-Christian knowledge and power.

sections.heading: Fire, Knowledge and the Dragon Within
sections.text:
Fire is what makes humans unique from animals, but the dragon is the animal that produces fire from within. This is because it is an energy being -- what it brings is vitality, through rain, fire or the currents of rivers and seas, rainbows and lightning. It's all vitality taking form, over which, as a shape shifter, the serpent is master. And the forms aren't just in the world -- as Plato describes, the forms are also ideas. So as the master of form, the dragon is the master of ideas and the shape-shifting of our consciousness that enables them.

When Siegfried became invincible by bathing in dragon's blood, but retained a weak spot where a leaf had remained on his body, this is like the weak spot of Achilles and the weak spot of metal when quenched. Dragon bones refer to the coal used to heat iron. The Placebo effect is very real, but it only works when the imagination expects to be healed. Dragons heal by healing the imagination. Dragons are killed to kill the imagination. There are no more powerful creatures in world mythology than dragons, and it's true everywhere.

sections.heading: Older Than Our Species
sections.text:
Snakes have been in our nightmares since before we were humans. By the time the first migrants were leaving Africa, our relationship with snakes, rivers, lightning and rainbows was already ancient. Imagination is older than humans -- so are its fears and associations -- and the association of snakes with death is as old as it gets. The question is when we began to make connections between the serpent and what shares its shape.

If there is a common origin to the dragon, it is not a region of the world, it's a region of the psyche. There are rivers and rainbows and spines and snakes and lightning bolts everywhere, and everywhere, they have roughly the same shape, and everywhere, there were poets and dreamers who saw this. Resolved conversations end. Answered questions are put to bed. Recurring myths are centered around undying concerns. As long as we're interested in the relationship of energy with matter and imagination with existence, the dragon will not lose its power.

dragons.overview: The dragon is energy that takes form — from rivers and flowing lava to chakras and rainbows. When serpent after serpent appears with mother after mother across world mythology, we see the same philosophy expressed: that all matter is energy taking form, and the master of form is the dragon. Where river valleys were never conquered, as in China, dragons are still honored. Where they were subdued, the dragon was demonized. But the dragon itself is not a tyrant — it is the flowing river, the lightning bolt, the rainbow of freedom.

sections.heading: The Lynchpin of Western History
sections.text:
Alexander is the lynchpin of Western History. Without Alexander, there is no transition from the golden age of Athens to millennia of Greco-Roman Empire. His victories ensured the centrality of Greek culture and thought to Western history. In just thirteen years, he conquered Greece, Persia, Israel, Egypt and India, spreading Greek culture across the known world. He was a hero-king who charged into battle to make the world in his image.

Alexander was the mark against which Caesar and the Roman emperors measured themselves. He was an example for Roman conquerors just like his empire was an example for Rome. When Caesar allied with Cleopatra, the tomb of Alexander came under the patronage of Rome, and Caesar, who imitated Alexander, would have seen the Roman acquisition of his divine body as a right to rule and evidence that his own conquest had been a continuation of the great legacy Alexander left behind.

sections.heading: The Conspiracy of Divine Blood
sections.text:
Arthur, Hercules, Christ, Alexander — according to myth, they were all conceived by a great father who came to their mother before she was known by her husband. It is a major motif from myth that shows up in the story of Alexander. His mother Olympias claimed he was the son of Zeus, for which reason he went to the oracle of Amun-Ra in Egypt, who was associated with Zeus by Alexander and the Greeks. Not only was he greeted as the son of God when he arrived, he also became a god when they elevated him to Pharaoh of Egypt.

According to the Ptolemies, the true father of Alexander was the exiled pharaoh of Egypt, Nectanebo II, who would have presented himself as a god to Olympias and who is depicted in art as a dragon, which aligns with a story of Philip's in which he found her sleeping with a snake. If these stories are true, the source of Alexander's divine blood is the same as his eventual recognition as God — Egypt and the line of pharaohs. The Pharaoh was known by the Jews as the great dragon. Not only did Alexander become a pharaoh, but according to the Ptolemies his true father was Nectanebo II, which could have to do with the dragon sometimes appearing on his banners.

sections.heading: Egypt's Liberator
sections.text:
The Egyptians have a history of preferring Greek partnership to Persian — a common enemy of Athens and Egypt for centuries, who had partnered together on defense. Though the Persians ruled as pharaohs of Egypt, when Alexander arrived with the army of Athens, he was received as their protector. Like Persian conquerors before him, Alexander became pharaoh of Egypt, but where these were recognized as invaders, Alexander was received as a liberator.

A legend arose that he was actually the son of the last free Egyptian pharaoh, Nectanebo, which aligned his mother's statement that he was the son of God. According to the legend, Alexander was a true Horus, a true son of the former pharaoh returned to seek vengeance on his father's betrayal. This is the myth of Osiris and Horus and Isis. Osiris is exiled by an invader. A sorceress queen then bears his son, who defeats the invading enemies of his father and becomes the rightful ruler of Egypt.

sections.heading: Achilles Reborn
sections.text:
Achilles was Alexander's Superman. Like pharaohs identifying with Horus when they go to war, he identified as the adored prototype for the role he wanted to play. New kings wear old crowns, and the mythic shoes into which Alexander wanted to step were those of Achilles, the warrior king. His was a repetition of a Trojan war in the east, against an enemy that offended all of Greece.

As the founder of Religious Studies, Mircea Eliade would say, New Year's ceremonies are recreations that retell the story of creation. Alexander's conquest was itself a recreation, a mythic repetition of the old war, carried out by a man who saw himself as the old hero reborn.

sections.heading: The Lost Tomb
sections.text:
The Vatican's authority over the Christian world has to do with the belief that it was built on St. Peter's tomb. Similarly, Alexandria's leadership of the Alexandrian world had to do with the presence of Alexander's tomb. If we start where we are born and end where we are buried, the tomb of a great leader is representative of where they left off, and the point from which the story continues.

Alexander was not just a historic figure. Because he was also remembered as a god, he was not just remembered, he was worshiped. So when Rome converted to Christianity and began persecuting pagans, his worshipers and temple were in jeopardy. Christians were minorities in Alexandria until 330 AD, and by 390, all signs of paganism were to be destroyed across Rome. Alexander's tomb could have suffered the same fate as so many other pagan monuments. In some cases, however, pagan sites were converted into Christian churches, which could have been the case with the magnificent tomb of Alexander. If it was repurposed for Christianity in the late fourth century, it is believed it could have been repurposed as the tomb of St. Mark. Centuries later, when the city's leadership was Muslim, two pilgrims from Venice are said to have stolen the body. When they returned, work began on what became St. Mark's Basilica. That they were both mummified makes it even harder to determine the truth.

alexander-the-great.overview: Alexander is the lynchpin of Western history — without him, there is no transition from the golden age of Athens to millennia of Greco-Roman empire. He saw himself as Achilles reborn, waging a mythic repetition of the Trojan War, and was received in Egypt as the true son of Ra, a liberator whose arrival fulfilled the myth of Horus returning to reclaim his father's throne. His lost tomb, like his legacy, sits at the intersection of worship and erasure, pagan splendor and Christian suppression.

sections.heading: Isis Incarnate
sections.text:
To understand Cleopatra, we have to understand the goddess with whom she identified — Isis, who, as a Greek, she recognized as Aphrodite, and who, as a Roman, Caesar knew as Venus, the consort of Mars. In the central narrative of ancient Egypt, Osiris is just a corpse. Isis is the star — Venus actually. And like an ancient superhero, she rescues her abducted lover and leads the conspiracy to save Egypt. She is the queen mother and protectress of Egypt and her family, a role to which she brings the full force of femininity.

Isis is a myth of feminine power, and we have been deprived of it. The persecution of witches is indivisible from the reduction of Isis in our collective conversation. Master of the mysteries, she is brilliant, powerful and nurturing, sexual and dignified. So too, was Cleopatra. Everyone else chose to be Horus. She chose to be Isis. She was not a female leader who modeled herself after men. She was a woman who drew power from her femininity. Imagine a woman as a head of state actually using her femininity. That was Isis. That was Cleopatra.

sections.heading: The Carpet, the Wand, and the Wings of Isis
sections.text:
When Cleopatra appeared to Caesar in a carpet, she appeared as the fabric of reality with which Isis was associated. In Latin, we see this connection in the word mater, which means both mother and matter, related to the word matrix. The matrix of reality is the maternal fabric of reality. Everything in our reality is born from that matter of mothers — this is the maternal matrix of matter. This is the carpet in which Cleopatra appears. She is not just offering herself, she is offering the wings of Isis — arms in which the world's greatest leader might truly rest. And he did.

Like the fairy that awakens Pinocchio with a spark from her magic wand, the first spark of Osiris' resurrection is delivered by a wooden phallus invented by Isis. So when Cleopatra is credited for inventing the vibrator, everyone in Egypt saw Isis. This recurring motif of the wand and life-spark concerns the mystery of life itself, a secret kept by Isis in the quiet of her cosmic womb, the source of all life.

sections.heading: Venus and Mars in the Flesh
sections.text:
Caesar referred to himself as the son of Mars, the Roman god of war, and Cleopatra identified as Isis-Aphrodite — Venus, for the Romans. In myth, Mars' lover is Venus. Historically, it is as though the myth came to life in the romance of Cleopatra and Caesar, Venus and Mars incarnate, love and power in the flesh. The greatest power couple in history would have to be Caesar and Cleopatra, in whom the conqueror met his match. But where he conquered with blades, she ruled with femininity.

When Cleopatra appeared to Marc Antony as Aphrodite, it was not a departure from her role as Isis, who, for the Greeks, was associated with their goddess of love. Alexander's conquest had led to an era of globalization that emphasized connections between gods from different regions. In Alexandrian Egypt, Isis was seen as Aphrodite. Her appearance to Antony in this form was both targeted seduction and, for her, part of her magic.

sections.heading: A Life Modeled on Myth
sections.text:
Cleopatra was modeling her personality and life after a myth long before her life was mythologized by painters and poets — and it shows. Her life was like a movie, which is why there are so many movies about her life. Like Isis, her goal was to bear a divine child that would lead a new world order, which is exactly what would have happened had she been able to clear a path for her son with Caesar, Caesarion. Had she succeeded, her people would not have been subdued by an invading force. Instead, Egypt would have been a partner in Rome.

We always see ourselves in every retelling of an old myth, and so we are always updating myths as mirrors of ourselves. We have had a different Cleopatra at different times in history. Sometimes she is a corrupting Eve, or Pandora, and sometimes she is an ultimate icon for feminine empowerment. By now, she is as much myth as she ever was history.

sections.heading: The Most Repressed Role Model
sections.text:
She is one of the best and most repressed role models in the history of human femininity. And it is because she is one of the most complete and empowered female role models in history that she is the most repressed. Every time you tell the story of Cleopatra, you remind the world that women can be powerful. If one woman could do it, others could as well. You are putting forward a role model and an option. It is hope for women and danger for men.

There has been a propaganda campaign against Cleopatra that is the same we have seen against Isis, witches, and Mary Magdalene — and it has to do with the way we see sexuality. Christians are always looking to retell the myth of Eve and to keep women in their places. So the story of Cleopatra gets turned into a story of Eve, because she is not in the place that the patriarchy would make for a woman. It is rare to have a single individual like Cleopatra who really transforms the trajectory of history, and she does it as one of the most complete and empowered women of all time.

cleopatra.overview: Cleopatra was not a female leader who modeled herself after men — she was a woman who drew power from her femininity, identifying as Isis incarnate in a world that would spend the next two millennia trying to suppress exactly that archetype. Her life was modeled on myth before it was mythologized by painters and poets, and her romance with Caesar was Venus and Mars in the flesh. She remains one of the best and most repressed role models in the history of human femininity.

sections.heading: The Pyramid as Ladder to Heaven
sections.text:
When the pharaoh dies, he becomes Osiris, son of the sun god who personified the djed pillar, a tree or ladder to heaven. To build a pyramid was to build Osiris' ladder to heaven — the pharaoh's ladder to Ra. The rise of the pyramids coincided with a rising emphasis on Re, as seen in the name of Djedef-Re. We translate it as "Enduring like Re," but djed does not just mean enduring — it refers to the djed pillar climbed by Osiris to reach Re. So when the pharaoh dies and becomes Osiris, what does he actually climb to reach the sun? A pyramid. The pyramid is a djed pillar, and Djedefre built one.

"I am he of the Djed pillar," says Osiris, as he enters the underworld — says the dead pharaoh, as he takes on the role of Osiris. The djed pillar is Osiris' ladder to heaven and forerunner of the pyramid. Like holy mountains and treetops, the root metaphor of a pyramid comes from the fact that it rises to the heavens. Eden, Zeus and the Ten Commandments — all on mountaintops. Pyramids inherit the mythological qualities of these holy mountains, where above meets below.

sections.heading: The Son of Ra
sections.text:
Djedefre was the first pharaoh to declare himself the son of Ra, which the pharaohs continued for thousands of years until even their conqueror, Alexander the Great, was received as Ra's Son. In the same way a divine monarch of Europe derives authority from a Christian god, a pharaoh derives authority from the sun god Ra, who governs the living day and guides our souls through night and death. As the lord of daily and annual rhythms, the sun presents an image of governance, leadership and stability.

The sun does not just govern the day; it journeys through night and promises a new sunrise. This is what we see in the Pyramid Texts: the journey of pharaohs, in the form of Osiris, from sunset to sunrise, from death to rebirth. In this journey we do not just see the resurrection of an individual — we see the annual return of Nile floods and the life they bring, we see the cyclical defeat of occupying invaders, and we see the eternal renewal of Egypt itself.

sections.heading: Built on the Mountain
sections.text:
Pyramids build on the symbolism of holy mountains. So when Djedefre literally built his pyramid on a mountain, he did not just save time; he also assimilated the meaning that was already associated with the local high point — like building a church from a pagan temple, he repurposed what was already there. No example is more clear than a mountain made into a pyramid: one holy high point becoming another. From Abu Rawash, one can look down on Giza. Since Djedefre built on a mountain, his pyramidion was twenty meters higher than that of Giza.

As the Egyptians later shifted away from pyramids, they began making tombs in mountains. This is for the same reason the fourth pyramid was built on a mountain — because the core symbolism was inspired by the mountain. The shape of the pyramid represents the hierarchical power structure of Ra governing the cosmos and the pharaoh governing Egypt. In the same way the sun at its height rules over creation, the pharaoh at his or her height rules over Egypt.

sections.heading: Pride, Fall, and the Cosmic Layout
sections.text:
There is the historical mystery about where all the stone went, and then there is the mythic narrative that comes through. This is the story of a hubristic rise and humbling fall: the story of a pharaoh who declares himself the son of god while building a ladder to heaven, which, like the Tower of Babel, came down. Through the eyes of the Jews, we see the fall of the Tower of Babylon and the fall of Eden, where the attempts of Eve and Satan to elevate themselves to divine status were met by exile and destruction.

If the pyramid complex at Giza is anything like other monuments and holy cities from around the world, each pharaoh was participating in a multigenerational plan. The layout of Giza would match the layout of the great Mexican pyramids if we can recognize the dark, distant pyramid as relating to storms. Distant from the great pyramid of the sun in Mexico City, built atop a higher mountain, is the temple of the moon, dedicated to the storm god. Similarly, the fourth pyramid was built atop a higher mountain at a bit of a distance, and it was not made to shine like the sun — it was covered in dark materials. The horned serpent in Djedefre's name connects to storm symbolism found around the world, from ancient China to Mexico.

fourth-pyramid.overview: The fourth pyramid at Abu Rawash is the story of a pharaoh who declared himself the first Son of Ra while building a ladder to heaven — and whose monument, like the Tower of Babel, came down. Djedefre built on a mountain, assimilating the holy symbolism already there, and his pyramidion stood twenty meters higher than Giza. Covered in dark materials where others shone like the sun, the fourth pyramid suggests a cosmic layout connecting sun and storm, mirroring patterns found from Mexico to China.

sections.heading: The Anatomy of Conspiracy
sections.text:
Conspiracy theories concern the conspiring of a small group around secret plans. This is not about the standard efforts of companies and governments to make money and expand power — conspiracy theories are about hidden powers. In the 2020s, it has become increasingly important to address our susceptibility to conspiracy theories and how big lies work. Why are bigger lies more convincing? Part of the reason is because they force us to find a way of thinking in which they might be true. This is enabled by the erosion of trust in "facts" by scientists who have auctioned their authority. The subsequent recognition that the truth of a motivation is more reliable than facts has led us to prioritize narrative.

Every PR firm, politician and storyteller is in the business of convincing. This is not the same as lying, but most of us know agendas to be developed and sold separately. What is said behind closed doors is not in commercials. This is where we get terms like Greenwashing and virtue signaling. The inability to know what is really going on leaves room for speculation, and within this room for speculation, everything is possible — including the notion that it is all connected.

sections.heading: The Inner Child and the All-Seeing Eye
sections.text:
Conspiracy theories present the world as more predictable and managed than the alternative, which plays off our childhood psyche. The first all-seeing eyes are those of our parents, who limit our freedom to keep us safe. This is nurturing for a child but oppressive to adults. Our inner child feels both comforted and stifled by the notion of a ruling elite. So whether you want something secure or something to rebel against, conspiracy theories fit the bill.

The eye of the Illuminati, like the eyes of the mother, makes us feel seen. On the other hand, to be watched is to be controlled. Some parts of us want there to be an Illuminati out there seeing us and watching us like Santa and Mom, affirming our existence. On the other hand, we do not want Mom or Hal or the Illuminati looking over our shoulder, controlling what we do. Ancient humans knew that an unseen group of predators could be tracking them at any moment, which set up an instinct to always be wary of unknown predators. This is how the fear of wolves becomes a fear of secret societies.

sections.heading: The Myth's Flexibility
sections.text:
The myth of the Illuminati is so successful because of its flexibility. Whatever your belief system is, you can find it in the Illuminati conversation. Are they a caring group who want to bring peace and enlightenment? Are they a secret cabal of tyrants? Is the world full of dupes? Whatever you want to believe, you can find it. Tolkien recognized that storytellers tend to ladle their narratives from a cauldron of stories — myths, folklore, religion and gossip, memories and dreams. The Illuminati myth is more grounded in the abstract concept of a ruling elite than a specific secret society.

The abstract notion of a secret elite is like a center of gravity that draws in historic and fictional examples that converge in the form of a myth. Once you are running with the essential mythology of a global elite, it is just a matter of time before every relatable image, figure and example becomes integrated. The all-seeing eye is a recurring symbol of omniscience. One could argue that it recurs because of some single society diffusing through time, secretly, or it could be because an eye on a mountain is simply a great metaphor for omniscience.

sections.heading: Patterns, Tricks, and Tunnel Vision
sections.text:
Humans are abstract geniuses who do not just see patterns everywhere, but even across the senses. We call cheese sharp, music soft, a touch sweet. Poetry and metaphor emerge when we synthesize recurring patterns. But we see what we are looking for and we are looking for confirmation. We spiral into delusion when we want confirmation enough to, consciously or unconsciously, ignore facts.

Magicians present partial truths to trick our belief. Conspiracy theories are like tricks. The more truth, the more convincing — like the aerial images of Karlsruhe and Washington, D.C. If you research what they look like, you can see the pattern quite clearly. The theory that it is because of the Illuminati, on the other hand, you cannot verify. But if one thing is true, many people tend to believe the other. Wayward conspiracy theorists and troubled gamblers are comparable: both maintain a sort of tunnel vision around their own beliefs and expectations, typically against the odds, despite their large bets.

sections.heading: The Irony of Enlightenment
sections.text:
The belief in a logical and coherent universe is more ancient than the Tao or Logos. But it was Newton who showed the math. This breakthrough, more than anything, gave birth to the Enlightenment. The real reason we adopted Enlightenment values is because the Newtonian paradigm was more convincing than the state or church — especially after Copernicus. When the Illuminati was formed, such covens were the rage, and Freemasonry was the gold standard.

The stated agenda of the Illuminati had everything to do with grounding the world in science and fact — that minds are lost in their pursuit is terribly ironic. We end up aligning around resonant narratives and psychologies more than facts, which we have come to believe are secondary to motive. This is exactly what the Illuminati was against, insofar as their stated agenda had everything to do with creating a more secular world grounded in science and fact.

illuminati.overview: Conspiracy theories present the world as more predictable and managed than the alternative, playing off our inner child's need for all-seeing parents. The Illuminati myth succeeds because of its extraordinary flexibility — whatever you want to believe, you can find it in the conversation. Beneath the paranoia lies a deep irony: the historical Illuminati was founded to ground the world in science and fact, and that minds are lost in pursuit of their myth is the most terribly ironic outcome of all.

sections.heading: History as Holy Myth
sections.text:
The journey of Jews through history is the arch narrative of their religious tradition, which is to say, their history is their myth and their myth is their history. Unlike other traditions that see mythic time as before history, for the Jews, God's plan turns history into an expression of mythic time. This creates a built-in expectation that historians will validate their cultural memories, and it turns that work into something that can look like a religious quest to prove that their myth is true.

Historical accuracy is an essential part of the religion. The Jewish understanding of history as a living out of God's plan gives religious significance to the historical validation of their mythic memories. So in the case of African Jews, DNA evidence becomes proof that their myth is historical, that they are part of the story, and that they, too, are chosen people. Before it was found, we thought Troy was just a myth. Could this be happening with the Lost Tribes of Israel?

sections.heading: The Trauma of Separation
sections.text:
For any Jew not in Israel, they know their family left, at some point, for some reason. This personal memory and experience of separation becomes colored by religious narratives that cast such departures as tragedy while calling for return. We see it in the exile from Eden and desire to return. We see it in the Babylonian exile. We see it in the story of lost tribes. And we see the traumatic displacement from home become core to Jewish histories yet again when they were exiled from Spain, and again when they were taken to concentration camps.

This deep trauma of separation and the desire to return is more than historical. As we see in the story of Adam and Eve, it is a repetition of their experience of separation from God. To be in Eden was to be with God. To be in Israel before the temple was destroyed was to be where God was. To be forced from the Garden was to be forced from God, which was to be alone in the world. To be a lost tribe is not just to participate in Jewish history; it is to participate in the divine journey of God's chosen people, which, for all Jews, provides a meaningful and divine context for all the struggles and suffering through which they have gone.

sections.heading: The Lemba and the Evidence
sections.text:
Trade routes tend to outline coasts and follow trade winds. The extension of trade to the African coast from the Arabian Peninsula was favored by both, which is why the migration route of the Lemba has become a superhighway for global trade. All we have to do is get over the delusional myth that ancient humans were not highly interconnected, and we will see that their journey is not beyond reason.

The story of the lost tribes is a mythical narrative believed to be real, and so we look for a convergence of mythic and literal evidence. Do they fit the story, and do the facts line up? Finding Sena in Yemen weaves facts into the narrative, from the boat and consistency of clan names to its intermediary position between Israel and Africa and the way it serves the story itself. DNA evidence is a hard fact, and when it aligns with the oral history of the Lemba and mythic memories of the Hebrews, and when deeper analysis shows so many similarities between their traditions, the question becomes hard to ignore.

sections.heading: The Sabbath River and the Other Side
sections.text:
When it is said that the ten tribes exist on the other side of the river which stops flowing on the Sabbath, the last day of creation, the meaning may be that the ten tribes exist on the other side of creation.
