God created the world in six days and rested on the Sabbath. The last day of the Roman week was also dedicated to the father god, Saturn, from whom we get the scythe-wielding figure that we know as Death. The rest of the Sabbath is like the rest we are talking about when we lay someone down to rest.

So when we see the association of the lost tribes with the Sabbath, and with a dry, still, lifeless river, we recognize the suggestion that these tribes are truly gone — maybe killed, maybe assimilated. This is a more poetic way of saying they are dead. To be on the other side of the Sabbath, on the other side of Saturn, the other side of the last day of creation, is to be beyond the realm of death.

sections.heading: The Law of Return
sections.text:
Jews whose families have long since left Israel can project their own story onto that of the lost tribes — estranged and with forgotten links to the home world, still an essential part of the community with a standing invitation to return, which is literally provided by the state of Israel. With Israel's Law of Return, the question of whether or not the African Jews are from a lost tribe becomes very important. If they are, they are entitled to a state-sponsored visit and right to return. This would mean the entire group, if elevated to Lost Tribe Status by the chief rabbi, could immigrate to Israel.

It is a strong link between religious and political matters. The prophets connect the returning of all Jews to Jerusalem with the coming of the Messiah, so it becomes a very important part of their faith. No tribes, no return, no Messiah. The lost tribes myth is a myth for Jews who cannot trace their lineage all the way back to Israel. It is a story that contains the desire to return and the desire to invite and the desire to make something new when that returning happens.

israels-lost-tribes.overview: The journey of Jews through history is the arch narrative of their religious tradition — their history is their myth and their myth is their history. The story of the lost tribes carries the deep trauma of separation from home and from God, from Eden to the Babylonian exile to the concentration camps. When DNA evidence aligns with the oral history of African Jews like the Lemba, the question of whether myth can also be history becomes impossible to ignore.

sections.heading: The Myth That Wove Egypt Together
sections.text: For millennia, the strength of the Egyptian state was contingent with the convincing coherence of its myth, which wove Egyptian life into a single tapestry. The Osiris myth modeled the journey of pharaohs, who modeled the journey of sun, season, crop, regime and the lives of Egyptian people, animals and plants — to say the least. Not only was the discovery of King Tut's tomb and treasure one of the greatest discoveries in modern archaeology, King Tut also played one of the most interesting roles in Egyptian history. His father was Akhenaten, who radically transformed the Egyptian religion into a kind of monotheism, which his son was forced to undo by the traditional priesthood.

sections.heading: The Birth of the Curse
sections.text:
There were definitely Egyptian curses concerning grave robbery, as seen on walls of pre-Pyramidal tombs in Giza. Shakespeare did the same thing. If you do not want people messing with your grave, put a curse on your tomb, whether you believe in it or not. That having been said, it seems such references were not required by performers who made shows of unwrapping mummies and popularized such notions of a curse well before the discovery of Tut.

Not only did the high-profile financier of the dig, an English noble, die a mysterious death, it was also written about and described as a curse by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, the author of Sherlock Holmes. On the back of a huge discovery, mysterious death and the contributions of a famed writer, the curse became a runaway hit. Despite various efforts to debunk the story, it was as big a hit as anything the author wrote, and now, after countless movies and spinoffs, the myth seems to be going nowhere.

sections.heading: Egyptomania and the Keyhole
sections.text:
Throughout the Victorian world, people were holding unwrapping parties in which they removed relics from the bandages of mummies. It was all the rage. When Tut was found, the Egyptomania exploded, and the curses — we all know the power of a good horror story. We might not like what we see, but we really want to look. Something about the tiny keyhole through which his treasures were first seen feels like a perfect metaphor. Egypt was far away — spatially, temporally, philosophically and mythically — our view was but through a keyhole.

The curse gave the archaeologists a juicy story without having to relent on giving press access. This did not just reduce their disappointment; it excited them more and their audiences even more still. The average life expectancy of those who were supposedly affected by the curse was actually longer than the average Englishman of the day — that does not sound so bad. And the mysterious death of the financier has been explained by a mosquito bite. So there may not have been a curse bringing down these archaeologists. That having been said, we do not want it gone from our movies.

curse-of-king-tut.overview: The discovery of King Tut's tomb was one of the greatest finds in modern archaeology, and the curse that followed was one of its greatest myths. Born from the mysterious death of a high-profile financier, amplified by the author of Sherlock Holmes, and sustained by Egyptomania, the curse became a runaway phenomenon. Beneath the spectacle lies a deeper story: a boy king forced to undo his father Akhenaten's radical transformation of Egyptian religion, and a civilization whose strength depended on the convincing coherence of its myth.

sections.heading: The Journey of the Sun
sections.text:
We see our own journey in the journey of the sun — from the projection of death on sunset to birth or rebirth on sunrise. What walks on four legs in the morning, two at midday, and three in the afternoon? This is the riddle of the Sphinx, and it points to the essence of solar symbolism. First and foremost, we see our journey in the sun's. We see our birth in sunrise, after which we crawl on all fours, and we see death in the sunset, before which we walk with a cane.

The Summer and Winter Solstice are the turning points of the year. At the Winter Solstice, the days transition from getting colder, darker, drier and more dead to warmer, wetter, brighter and more alive. And it is not just the resurrection of nature we associate with this solar return — this is also the core metaphor for the resurrection of an individual, which is why Easter is celebrated at sunrise. For Neolithic humans, the winter solstice was not just the first light of a new year. It was also the beckoning of new light in all journeys, including a loved one's journey through death.

sections.heading: Participation Against Estrangement
sections.text:
There is a big leap you have to take to understand megaliths, and it is not that hard, but you have to take it. Megaliths are about participation — participation with nature, participation with the cosmos and with other humans. By aligning the individual with the rituals of the monument, the individual became aligned socially, professionally and spiritually, with each other and their world.

From Adam and Satan to a modern shooter, the pain they feel is estrangement — separation from the divine and from one another. That is why we go to music festivals and parties and churches — to be with, to be in participation — with each other and our world. Aligning rituals with monuments aligned with the heavens and earth created an existential experience of alignment between the individual and their reality, which is perhaps the most important experience for a human. When people participate in ritual together, they do not feel alone, and loneliness is one of the great curses of humanity, which can turn into hate and violence if not resolved.

sections.heading: Crossing the Threshold
sections.text:
Entering a megalithic temple was like crossing the threshold between day and dream. The shift into darkness and chanting with ritual objects and symbolic imagery was accompanied by a shift in consciousness from daily life to participation in mythic time. To enter an ancient temple or the ritual caves that came before them was to enter a womb, the source and center of all creation. And that is how it felt — to be in the source and center of meaning.

Entering a dark temple is a full sensory experience. Your eyes will have to adjust to the darkness within seconds. There are only little flickering lights of candles illuminating the space. Next thing you see are life-sized images of saints who stare directly at you. It smells of incense, the temperature drops. Your entire body is forced to immediately adapt. And then there is deep and rhythmic chanting piercing through your body. That hits every sense.

sections.heading: Monuments of Humility and Brilliance
sections.text:
Slaves did not build these things. They were built by communities who wanted to align with their cosmos for spiritual and practical reasons. Celebrations at these monuments would be hard to distinguish from parties. There was even fun involved, maybe love, maybe sex, and certainly celebration. In a pre-literate society, the paper on which they wrote was nature itself. Instead of putting ink to paper, they put stone to earth.

These monuments should be humbling, first and foremost. They are the death of arrogance. Anyone who thinks they can explain them fully runs up against something impossible they have to leave out. How were stones moved, how were they cut and placed, and how in the hell do you get the level of mass participation required to build them? Because ancient humans did not have the tools we have, we tend to think they were not as smart as we are, but there is no evidence of this. In fact, writing reduced many of our brain's capacities. So when we look back at ancient humans and their monuments, it is important to not dismiss ancient brilliance.

sections.heading: Setting Tea Times with the Cosmos
sections.text:
Many megalithic monuments are solar calendars, some are lunar calendars, some track the movements of Venus and some track the journey of earth through its seasons. Calendar, however, is a reductive term. They were not just keeping time. They were participating in it. If you know when teatime is, you can have tea with everyone — emphasis on, with everyone. Modern lovers of astrology may want to know what is going on up there so they know how it is influencing them down here, but what alignment with the heavens is really about is just alignment — it is about setting tea times with the cosmos.

Megaliths are like time machines — on one hand, they were machines used for the measurement of time, and on another, they traveled to the future and take us to the past. In the first well-documented epic quest for immortality, Gilgamesh landed on the conclusion that his immortality would be preserved in a stone monument. To participate in the building of an enduring monument is to transcend the limited range of time in which the individual lives.

megaliths.overview: Megaliths are about participation — with nature, with the cosmos, and with one another. These monuments were not just calendars; they were machines for aligning the individual with the rhythms of earth and sky, creating an existential experience of belonging in a species haunted by estrangement. Built by communities, not slaves, they are the death of arrogance — monuments of humility and brilliance that remind us ancient humans were no less intelligent than we are, and that they wrote on the earth itself because they had no paper.

sections.heading: The Patriarch's Worst Nightmare
sections.text:
Can you imagine a worse nightmare for patriarchy than a matriarch on its throne? Beneath the story of a scandalous affair and its defiance of church law is a more profound challenge to patriarchy itself. And it is not just divine patriarchy. Pope Joan is a reminder for paternal kings and husbands that mothers control creation. A new image of a pope giving birth would be as subversive today as it was in the time of Pope Joan. It is like the graffiti of a punk artist saying, oh, so you think a patriarch has the monopoly on divinity and creation all by himself? He cannot even do this. Women literally have the authority to create life.

Pope Joan offers a particularly pointed example of the eternal power struggle between men and women. This story is older than our species and it continues to this day — in every government, in every business, in every relationship and every psyche. Straight, gay, bi, trans, he, her, they, them — there is not a person to whom the inner and outer power struggle of femininity and masculinity does not matter.

sections.heading: Eve on the Papal Throne
sections.text:
Pope Joan is a perfect shadow figure for a medieval Christian worldview that presented Mary, a virgin, as the ideal woman. Where Mary conceives without intercourse or lust, Pope Joan is just Eve — a disobedient seductress who hides her sin from the divine patriarchy. This is not just a story of feared femininity; it is a paranoia about its ability to secretively climb the ladder. Would the whole church have become filled with witches in hiding?

The demonization of Pope Joan is a repetition of hatred for Eve, and what that hatred represents is an anger at having fallen. This is the fall of spirit into matter. Matter is not just seen as a prison that corrupts the soul; it is also the word for Mother. As matter and body are seen as corrupting prisons of falling consciousness, the mother becomes a representative of the fall and a personification of corruption with a seductive body. For the same reasons, Pope Joan became associated with the Whore of Babylon.

sections.heading: Better Than the Men at Their Own Game
sections.text:
This is the story of a world in which women have to be as a man to succeed, and in these stories — some fictional, some real, some ongoing — it is not enough for a woman to be as good as the men. She has to run circles around them to even be noticed. At the same time, this is the story of how powerful a person can be in a male-dominated world if they just integrate a little feminine. She may out-male the men at their own games, but she is also a woman, and she has qualities they have not engaged. As a more whole person, she runs circles around her peers.

On the surface, Joan out-mans the men as a leader and scholar who the men all recognize as an ultimate male patriarch. Beneath the surface, however, she is a perfect Eve — not only does she disobey the divine patriarchy for sinful sex with a presumably innocent man, she becomes a personification of exactly what the Christian consciousness is trying to oppress, repress and purify.

sections.heading: The Repressed Returns
sections.text:
Pope Joan is a personification of exactly what the church represses, and her birth in the Pope's clothing represents that which has been repressed finally forcing its way to the surface. Such a disruption, however, is only an inciting incident — an inciting incident that reformers experienced as a call to adventure, a call to change. Reform always follows disruption, in the self and in the world, and this disruption tends to take the form of a subversive act by a shadow figure that personifies exactly what her culture represses, oppresses and needs.

There will always be reformers, and they will always preserve stories that criticize the status quo. If the status quo had truly changed, if the Church had fully reformed, the story might no longer be on our minds. Until and unless there is real change, the reformers of our day will renew the cries of their predecessors. Wastelands are defined by the vitality they marginalize and repress. By now, our marginalization of the feminine is inseparable from the threats of climate change and nuclear extinction. But though the west has been defined by its oppression of femininity, our times are defined by its rise.

pope-joan.overview: Pope Joan is a story older than its alleged historical moment — the eternal power struggle between masculine and feminine expressed as the ultimate infiltration. Can you imagine a worse nightmare for patriarchy than a matriarch on its throne? Beneath the scandal lies a more profound challenge: a reminder that mothers control creation, that women can outperform men at their own games, and that whatever a culture represses will eventually force its way to the surface.

sections.heading: The Great Wiping Clean
sections.text:
Flood myths can be found all over the world, and they typically separate mythic time from real time — it is the great wiping clean of the time before time. Because the earliest cities were dependent on flooding rivers, floods did not just bring danger, they brought fertility to the fields. While the annual floods brought annual renewal, the great flood brought the renewal of an entire epoch, like a collective baptism.

From the films of Roland Emmerich to Revelations, Apocalypse stories represent the projection of our own mortality onto that of our species. This is a natural thought, so it is a natural myth — from the Great Conflagration of the Stoics to the asteroid in Armageddon. But where death and resurrection provide metaphors for the renewal of an individual, Apocalypse is about the renewal of humanity.

sections.heading: Many Floods, One Myth
sections.text:
When you look at the horizon, it comes to a point — the same happens with the mythic imagination. The distant memory of multiple major floods likely converged to form these myths: the melting of glaciers, the river floods of ancient cities, perhaps a flood in the Black Sea. And floods are traumatizing. Myths then serve these memories while responding to the trauma and delivering wisdom.

Real events can definitely become myths and we should always look for the potential histories beneath the surface. That having been said, flattening myths to a single historic event is often misguided. The flood in Hebrew mythology is believed to have been influenced by the Sumerian flood myth, which is likely to have been influenced by the civilization's annual floods and potentially that of the Black Sea. It is most common for historical memories to become embellished with mythic motifs over time — especially with oral narratives, which are not fixed in writing.

sections.heading: Fear, Change, and the Unknown
sections.text:
The fear of the end of the world is a projection of the end of the self, which we all fear. People do not just fear the end of the world; they fear change and displacement. Catastrophes always come with major change — that means entering the unknown. Myths help us to imagine the unknown, which makes it less scary.

The Old Testament god was known for his wrath. And like other divine patriarchs, he carries qualities of a storm god, who expresses his anger in the form of a storm. Real people survived real floods and have had real experiences like Noah's. Today's events will most certainly become mythologized. By now we have already seen the nuclear bomb and major recent wars in our culture's most popular stories. Humanity's biggest catastrophes will continue to inspire our biggest myths — from Hiroshima to the global warming which may actually bring the first worldwide flood experienced by humans.

great-flood.overview: Flood myths separate mythic time from real time — the great wiping clean of the time before time. Because the earliest cities depended on flooding rivers, floods brought not just danger but fertility, and where annual floods brought annual renewal, the great flood brought the renewal of an entire epoch. The distant memory of multiple real floods likely converged to form these myths, and they persist because they carry our deepest anxiety: the projection of our own mortality onto that of our species.

sections.heading: The Most Famous Prophet
sections.text:
If Merlin is the most famous wizard, Nostradamus is the most famous prophet. In the last five hundred years, there has been hardly a disaster, tyrant or pandemic not seen in his quatrains. From John the Revelator to the Oracle of Delphi, no prophet is more famous today than Nostradamus. His prophecies — especially those to which we gravitate — tend to focus on disaster. Disastrous deaths, disastrous leaders, disastrous pandemics and wars. Society would like to avert disaster, and so prophecies catch our ears.

Whenever something catastrophic happens in the world, the name Nostradamus always falls in media reports. People are looking to validate their beliefs. Those who want to believe in prophecy and what that means to them will see Nostradamus hit the mark. Those who want to believe there is no such thing will find fault. Both can be projected on the range of possible interpretations.

sections.heading: Patterns in Time
sections.text:
When Tolkien was pressed to admit that Lord of the Rings was about World War I, he replied that the audience's closeness to World War I is what enabled them to see what he recognized as recurring narratives. Nostradamus seems to have similarly accessed perennial patterns through the comparison of historic repetitions with the time in which he lived. His observations of the present suddenly sound strongly like the past events of which he had read: epochs of religious discord, revolutions, ostracisms and civil wars seem catapulted into his time. He realizes that the future of his country looks like the destroyed past.

Civilizations thrive on good predictions — from the anticipation of seasons to global warming and the forecast of earnings. This is what meteorologists are after, and astrologers. Both are trying to turn patterns in the sky into earthly predictions.

sections.heading: The Logic of Oracles
sections.text:
Astrology is to Tarot as Relativity is to Quantum Mechanics. Where astrology is all about the regularity of stars, Tarot is about god's dice. Delphic prophecies, on the other hand, look more like interpreted dreams. What they all share in common is metaphor, on which every oracle depends. Reading the stars is about interpreting the movements of the macrocosm as movements in the microcosm. As above so below — as without so within.

Ancient civilizations tended to represent their vision of the heavens in the construction of their cities and the configuration of their courts. On earth as it is in heaven. World religions and mythologies repeatedly present a vision of the individual as a piece or recreation of the creator or cosmos. And from this perspective, one might ask if there is entanglement between the shifting of inner and outer constellations, of macro and microcosmos.

sections.heading: Trance, Code, and the Surreal
sections.text:
By writing poetry in a trancelike state, Nostradamus was a predecessor of the Surrealists and David Lynch, who seek access beyond their conscious mind. Neuroscientific studies on mystics — especially Tibetans — have shown that altered states of consciousness can open access to thoughts and insights that would be otherwise inaccessible.

Nostradamus would not have been the first to encode a message in his poetry — in the metaphors of his imagery or the math of his meter. Both encode meaning in the Tarot, in Alchemical Recipes and Astrological interpretations. Poetry and meter bring math to language, which is often seen in sacred texts. From the quatrains of Nostradamus to the Talmud and Rig Veda, mystics look for codes. When looking for hidden meanings and codes, a misprint or misplacement — even of a comma or single letter — can make all the difference.

sections.heading: Prophecy and the Future
sections.text:
Anticipating what is going to happen is a survival skill — literally and emotionally. Whether it is anticipating a predator or a war, a harvest or a romantic connection, we anticipate to avoid suffering and pursue happiness. Our desire to avoid suffering and pursue happiness, however, can motivate us to believe in prophecies that might not be as justified as we want to believe. Convincing ourselves we know the future gives us a sense of control — justified or not.

Prophecy may not be provable or even probable, but it is not scientifically disqualified either. There are some interesting qualities of time, entanglement and M-Theory that raise questions about the participation of our future in the present. In the last few years, major shows like Westworld and Devs have featured the idea of predicting the future with algorithms. Jung was wary of this. The problem is that while the probabilities predicted by Quantum Mechanics are incredibly accurate, variation and anomaly is part of the prediction. The question becomes whether it is irresponsible, if not tyrannical, to impose a statistical prediction on the individual level.

nostradamus.overview: Nostradamus is to prophecy what Merlin is to wizardry — the most famous practitioner of a tradition far older than himself. Writing poetry in a trancelike state, he accessed perennial patterns through the comparison of historic repetitions, recognizing that the future of his country looked like its destroyed past. His quatrains persist because they operate on metaphor, the language of every oracle, and because the desire to anticipate disaster is a survival instinct as old as humanity.

sections.heading: Goddesses Fallen into Witches
sections.text:
As patriarchs rose, goddesses fell, and as they did, they turned into witches. Isis and Inanna were heroines, but when Inanna became Ishtar, the heroine became an enemy. Gaia was beloved, but in Greek mythology her human incarnation, Pandora, like Eve, is to blame for all suffering. This represents a shift in our relationship with the feminine and nature that turned women into witches and Eden into a fallen world.

The word "witch" comes from the same root as "wit," which means clever. Prometheus was clever. The clever one, in myth, is a revolutionary, and the State, like Zeus in the story of Prometheus, has a tendency to want to put down the clever ones. So the silencing of witches is the silencing of rebellious cleverness, and in the case of the European witches, this cleverness had to do with the knowledge and wisdom of Europe that Christianity worked to completely snuff out.

When Rome converted to Christianity, it demonized paganism, which became a catch-all for any belief system the new order opposed. The conflation of feminine and pagan enmity gives us the witch. Pagan gods became Christian demons and pagans became devil worshippers. Suppressed during the Roman period, the bloody conflict between Christian truth and paganism repeated in the Medieval era, and once Christendom encompassed Europe, much of what was seen as witchcraft was simply pagan and foreign.

sections.heading: The Patriarchal Fear of Feminine Power
sections.text:
The mythical story of the witch is deeply intertwined with masculine envy of the mother's power of creation. The power of creation comes from the wombs of nature, not the mechanisms of human effort. Fundamentally, men do not have the power to create, which means they live alongside a partner-gender with a supreme divine power that they cannot even begin to match. Fear and inferiority complexes start to create narratives that demonize and minimize this power in women.

Women are often experienced by men as more psychologically advanced, meaning they are more capable of manipulating them. Whether they do or not, the capacity is recognized, feared and reacted against. Thus we see narratives that demonize the feminine capacity to enchant. We all fear enchantment when it comes to love, and from a masculine perspective, negative romantic enchantments that ended in suffering are remembered in the mythic record by those in power. In a man's world, the one to blame will always be the woman.

The other major experience of overwhelming feminine power is that of the mother from the perspective of the child. Thus we see wonderful fairy godmothers and terrible wicked witches throughout our folklore. These are not just representations of our various ways of relating to femininity and the power of nature, they are also representations of our various ways of experiencing the mother. The mother has absolutely overwhelming power over the child, who is completely dependent on the mother, like a human is on the earth. In a world controlled by men, all of these masculine fears, insecurities and resentments of nature, creation, mothers, lovers and women come together in the image of the witch.

sections.heading: Man vs. Nature, Man vs. Witch
sections.text:
Patriarchy does not just oppress women; it suppresses those qualities with which it associates femininity, which are typically some combination of nature, body, emotion and pleasure. The man's world and consciousness is built on the subdual of these things, which it projects onto the witch. The demonization of one becomes the demonization of the other, and this does not just mean the mistreatment of women, it means the mistreatment of all that is associated with femininity within each man. This is what toxic masculinity looks like.

The annihilation of witches is inseparable from the rise of emphasis on human manipulation of the material world. Man vs. Witch is actually a Man vs. Nature story. The witch represents the forces of nature and creation that the Enlightenment paradigm wanted to repress. Their vision of the world was a vision of dead matter interacting in purely mechanical ways. There is no magic in this system, which means there was no room for witches in this paradigm.

Built into the Classical and Christian stories about the origins of knowledge and humanity is an association of the feminine with materiality. This is why "mater" relates to both mother and matter. The material world is the mother's world, and like earth, the mother possesses the power of creation. Where patriarchy reduces matter to dead stuff, bodies become seen as dead stuff. The material world with which mothers are associated shifts from being seen as alive with the power of creation to being seen as a lifeless machine. To reduce matter to bodies comes with the reduction of women to bodies.

sections.heading: The Devil, the Witch, and the Fallen World
sections.text:
The reason witches are associated with the devil is because the Devil has come to be associated with the powers of nature, which is understood in a Christian consciousness as Fallen. Nature is constantly corrupting the soul, which is symbolized by the seductions of Pandora and Eve, who draw masculine consciousness into the fallen material world. This fallen world is the domain of devils as much as it is the domain of women. From this perspective, the womb is not a great power of creation; it is the portal through which souls fall. The seduction of the devil and the seduction of the woman are one.

Once we recognize the association of the woman with the mortal and material, we understand why witches are so frequently beautiful or aged. They are beautiful to represent the seductive nature of the material world. They are aged to represent the dreaded reality of aging that comes from entering the body and its mortal material world. In the aged witch we see the transference of our own anxieties around aging and death.

sections.heading: Brooms, Flight, and Modern Reclamation
sections.text:
The great Slavic witch, Baba Yaga, flies through the sky in a bucket and covers her tracks with a broom. In myth, when women are hurt, silenced and disempowered, they tell their stories where they can, in blankets and in clay. As they do, the domain to which they are relegated becomes their center of power. We see the symbols of Baba Yaga, her totems of power, the pail and broom, as domestic objects. But for a witch, for a storyteller, we can fly on these things. In the dead of night, where no one else sees, the details of children's stories give form to our future.

The witch is a mythic battleground for our relationship with magic, femininity and nature. The enemy of the witch is her demonization, but today her momentum is empowerment. As the shadow of toxic masculinity, she turns us around, and as a beacon of all that has been repressed with the feminine, she leads the way.

What is the real witch's balm? How can they really heal us? Their very demonization is an expression of our cultural imbalance and the toxicity that comes with such an imbalance towards the masculine, which is away from nature, away from body, away from emotion and pleasure. By now, we can see a future of emotionless uploaded consciousness in robots on dead planets far away from our earth. Witches are balm for this traumatic fantasy and its real world consequences.

witches.overview: As patriarchs rose, goddesses fell, and as they did, they turned into witches. The word witch comes from the same root as wit — cleverness — and the silencing of witches is the silencing of rebellious knowledge that Christianity worked to snuff out across Europe. Man versus witch is actually man versus nature, and the annihilation of witches is inseparable from the rise of a paradigm that reduces the living world to dead matter. The witch is balm for this reduction, and her momentum today is empowerment.

sections.heading: Soul and Breath, Body and Clay
sections.text:
Most cultures describe the awakening of first humans as an integration of fire, breath or divine essence with a clay or dough-like body. This symbolic distinction of soul and body predates the mind-body dualism of Descartes and Socrates by a large margin, as does the overlap of words for breath, air and spirit. Pneuma, for example, in Greek.

When you see someone moving and then just stop dead, it is like something is gone, they are gone. This is so basic I am not sure dogs do not believe in ghosts; in fact, many ancient cultures thought they could see them.

sections.heading: The Greatest Confirmation We Seek
sections.text:
Death is the greatest of human concerns, and seeing a ghost would be the ultimate confirmation that life does not just end, not for you and not for your loved ones, some of whom may already be gone. To the extent we want evidence that life does not just end, we want stories of ghosts. And if there is an afterlife, and there are ghosts, they would probably be everywhere.

The beliefs of different cultures in the soul and afterlife are modeled in their myths, often in the form of ghosts, shades or spirits. The various beliefs about the afterlife then inflect the disposition of their ghosts. In Greece, Herakles' shade is found in Hades while another part of his being went to Olympus. In China, to be a ghost means you are too attached to move on, too attached to your appetites, for which reason you are punished with a tiny mouth. These are called "hungry ghosts."

sections.heading: Cultural Lenses on the Paranormal
sections.text:
The different beliefs cultures take towards ghosts tend to emerge from their deepest worldviews, which are informed by religion, science and more. Catholics, for example, are far more receptive to ghosts than Lutherans. In Germany, free thinking, superstition and metaphor were attacked by Catholic inquisitions and Protestant literalism. England suffered none of these, and their history centers around global trade of both goods and ideas. That England is more receptive to the possibility of ghosts than Germans should come as no surprise.

Modern science does not disqualify the possibility of ghosts. Enlightenment science did, and the Western consciousness responsible for the Enlightenment still struggles with modern physics. This is not as true in India or Japan, where they do not suffer the same Enlightenment hangover or the Western predispositions that led to delusional dismissiveness and reductive thinking.

sections.heading: Confronting Death's True Face
sections.text:
Thinking about ghosts is thinking about death, which most of us choose not to do on a daily basis. The confronting of a ghost is a confrontation with death, and not just because the ghost is dead and might kill us, but because the very being of a ghost forces an existential confrontation with death. The fact that we make ghosts scary and tell scary stories about them is like putting a Halloween mask on a face of true horror.

Some ghost phenomena can be explained by science, but other scientific explanations depend on assumptions and reductive either-or logic. The bigger question is: if science can explain a phenomenon, does that mean it cannot be a soul? Science can model and map the movement of neurochemistry in the brain and associate it with mental activity, but it cannot translate into the language of subjective experience. The same may be true with ghosts. We may be able to see weird energetic phenomena, but that does not mean we can dismiss the possibility of a subjective experience pertaining to that energy. Science, left to its own devices, will deny subjective consciousness in our own brains.

ghosts.overview: Seeing a ghost would be the ultimate confirmation that life does not just end — not for you, not for your loved ones. The desire for this evidence is universal, which is why ghost stories appear in every culture, shaped by the deepest beliefs of each. From the Greek shade of Herakles split between Hades and Olympus to the Chinese hungry ghost punished for attachment, every culture's ghosts reveal what that culture most fears and hopes about death, consciousness, and the possibility that something survives the body.

sections.heading: The Modern Prometheus
sections.text:
Sensorium Dei means that we are the sensory organs of the divine. Scientists who shared this perspective were not just trying to decode a secular universe. They wanted to know the mind of God. Emboldened by the discovery of electricity, Calculus and the Copernican revolution, scientists asked questions where before there were limits. They wanted to unlock the mystery of life.

Prometheus, the bringer of technology, strains against boundaries as bondage. There are scientists and there are inventors. There are clerks and entrepreneurs, priests and shamans. Priestly scientists are like clerks who maintain the orthodox. But innovators, like Prometheus and Frankenstein, like shamans and entrepreneurs, break boundaries to go their own way. Frankenstein, the modern-day Prometheus, wrestles limitation itself. The fire he brings is not just the conscious vitality that animates his creatures, it is the technologies that enable revolution against the status quo.

sections.heading: Playing God and Crossing Boundaries
sections.text:
Wernher von Braun said the rocket would open the gates of heaven by freeing us from our chains. All innovation is against the bondage of some status quo: labor and disease, life on this planet. This is why Prometheus, the innovator, is always wrestling with chains. Technologies, from weapons to cures, rebel against the possible. But by rebelling against mortality, the human condition itself, Frankenstein crossed the ultimate boundary.

What constitutes playing God? Dissecting the body was once seen as off limits. Stem cells have been seen as off limits. Both, however, have saved lives. Some see a challenge to the natural order in the coronavirus vaccine; some see a technology saving souls. Where we all seem to stop and hold our breath, however, is when we are messing with mortality itself, when we try to stop death entirely and when we create life on our own. Frankenstein dared both.

sections.heading: The Monster and the Name
sections.text:
Frankenstein is not the name of the monster; it is the name of his creator, Victor Frankenstein, Doctor Frankenstein. But are we supposed to make this leap? To recognize the creation in the image of its creator? Or should our recognition of the monster as Frankenstein set us up to see Frankenstein as the monster?

Adam can be translated as red clay, which is no more a name than "Monster." The Golem did not have a name either; it was animated by God's word. Such animation by a name is about the relationship of name with soul, or essence. To question the monster's name is to question the monster's soul. Vampires, mummies and Frankenstein's monster are all awakened corpses. Each asks its questions of body and lifeforce.

sections.heading: A Lineage of Promethean Creators
sections.text:
Frankenstein highlights a lineage of Promethean figures who challenge the natural order, from the necromancy of Dr. Faustus to the alchemical creation of a Golem, the metallurgical creation of Sosruquo and the pharmaceutical creation of Mr. Hyde. These creators refocus the revelations of science on a revolution against nature, if not the divine.

The story of Frankenstein is not just told and retold. The figure has updated and informed our stories of playing God, of creator and creation, of consciousness and body, which we continue to see in Ultron, Ex Machina, Data from Star Trek, or David from Ridley Scott's Prometheus. We are in the middle of a digital revolution that is seeing the convergence of AI, robotics, mind mapping and virtual reality, all of which have opened Pandora's box to the potential of a new Frankenstein.

sections.heading: We Are Already Post-Technology
sections.text:
We are already a post-technology species. Our brain grew when our stomach shrunk when we discovered cooking. No fire, no humans. Does the blind man end at his hand or his cane? How about his pacemaker? How about our smartphones? How reliant are our lives on power, internet, genetically modified foods, vaccines? And if we can recognize we are at least somewhat artificial, why should we resist something artificial becoming somewhat biological?

The question of whether or not we will replicate a human should be broken into three levels. First, will humans be able to learn all the scientific principles that make us human? The next question is whether we will be able to master and manipulate the physical principles that make us human. And then there is the much bigger question: is there something beyond the natural or scientific that makes us human? This is where it becomes a question about the soul and free will.

frankenstein.overview: Frankenstein is the modern Prometheus — the innovator who wrestles limitation itself, whose fire is not just the spark of life but the technologies that enable revolution against the status quo. Mary Shelley's creation asks the question that every subsequent story of playing God has inherited: is there something beyond the natural or scientific that makes us human? From the Golem to Ex Machina, the boundary Frankenstein crossed — creating life, defying mortality — remains the one that makes us all hold our breath.

sections.heading: Haitian Origins and the Enslaved Soul
sections.text:
On one level, we can see a historical entry of the current zombie mythology through the enslavement of Africans in Haiti, where there is a local belief in zombies and from which our stories of zombies first emerged. In the Haitian Vodou tradition, the soul is believed to consist of two parts: the ti bon ange, which carries free will and personality, and the gros bon ange, which operates the body and its needs. A Vodou master steals the victim's soul, and that is how he controls the zombie. The zombie is the perfect slave.

This structure is not present in the mind-body dualism that dominated Western Christian consciousness. The ghost in the machine is the spirit that moves the body and the personality it brings. As long as the energy that animates the body and the free-thinking personality are not recognized as distinct, we cannot imagine an animated body without a mind. We see precursors trying to help us think this way in the form of the Golem of Prague, which is animated but does not have a soul. The zombie, emerging from the Haitian tradition, is capable of animation without the presence of personality or free will.

The Zombie emerged from overlapping shadows of slavery and the scientific reduction of humanity to bodies of dead matter with no free will. In the zombie we see the objectification of humans become spirit-killing enslavement that results in mass uprisings. And so they appear as a warning, if not a threat: objectify others at your own risk.

sections.heading: Dead Matter and the Nightmare of No Free Will
sections.text:
The zombie is a dead body with no free will and a conformist need to consume. For centuries, this is the description to which scientists have been reducing all of us: bodies of dead matter with no free will and a drive to consume to which we conform. From the birth of Greek philosophy through the Enlightenment, the direction of science was towards the recognition of matter as dead stuff with no free will, which led to the reduction of our bodies to dead matter that conforms to conditions. This belief system is represented in the zombie, which reveals its nightmarish nature.

Zombies reflect an image of humanity with no free will, that our bodies are made of dead matter but enslaved by their need to consume. That they have emerged from several sources to so poetically represent these concerns is a reflection of how wary we are of our own consumerism, conformity and belief in dead matter. In the last century, scientists have learned that our bodies, like the earth, are not just dead matter, that matter is not enslaved to causality.

sections.heading: Mirrors of Conformity
sections.text:
The zombie is used to show us where and how we conform. When we see them on the streets in work clothes or school uniforms, we are seeing the modes of life through which we can act like zombies. Are employees encouraged to think for themselves? Are students given agency to choose what they learn? Can we fall into routine through a relationship? Can we give our minds over to politics, or religion? Zombies show up to help us see where we are at risk of not thinking for ourselves. They teach us not to become puppets.

Monsters are mirrors for our own shadow, the part of ourselves we repress. We repress how much we conform and how little we think. We do not want to admit we are conformists. We do not want to believe that consciousness is an illusion. So these fears take form, and the form they take is the zombie: a mirror for our own repressed conformity. The zombie is a mirror for our enslavement. A zombie wearing a tie or school uniform is a mirror for our own experience of life and school. In Revelations, it is said that when we see the face of the beast, we will rebel from it. When we see ourselves in the zombie, we cannot abide.

sections.heading: The Few Against the Many
sections.text:
In most zombie stories today, we follow a few brave survivors who face an overwhelming horde, which leads us to identify with that elite one percent at odds with the masses. But who are the zombie hordes? Are we just thinking about a literal zombie apocalypse, or do we project our fear of overpopulation onto populations we other, shadow and demonize? Upper classes have always associated themselves with a higher caste and often with the head or crown, and they have often seen the masses as the body. The zombie conflict is one of the head against the body, the many against the few.

Where vampires tend to be associated with a powerful elite, zombies represent the enslaved masses, which overthrow their world and its government, represented by the eating of brains, the part of us with control and consciousness. Where vampires lack a soul, zombies lack free will. And while the craving of vampires has a sexual energy, the zombie's is a brain-killing hunger.

sections.heading: The Demonization of Vodou
sections.text:
When most of us think of Vodou, we think of voodoo dolls and witch doctors, which leads to the demonization of a real religion and the people who practice it. A zombie is simultaneously a Haitian monster and victim of Vodou, and in both forms, it serves to scare us further away from even wanting to understand its practitioners or traditions. What becomes curious is how many Black American Christians might take interest in Vodou, an American-born Black tradition that draws from African roots, if it were not so demonized. And at the same time, how the demonization of this Black tradition serves to reinforce racism. In either case, keeping Vodou so demonized is a way to keep it subdued throughout the North American hemisphere.

The zombie is fundamentally about enslavement, which is, unfortunately, an ongoing global experience with a boundaryless history. Once the severe African experience of enslavement gave rise to a global awareness of the figure, it became infused by all the global examples of comparable figures. Recognizing the connection between enslavement and hypnosis, films like Get Out and Us present a vision of the world as puppeted and hypnotized by public narratives. The stories through which we are hypnotized result in shadows, which get locked away.

zombies.overview: The zombie emerged from overlapping shadows of Haitian slavery and the scientific reduction of humanity to bodies of dead matter with no free will. In the Vodou tradition, the zombie is the perfect slave — a body animated without personality, will, or agency. In the modern imagination, they mirror our own conformity, our enslavement to consumption, and the nightmare possibility that consciousness is an illusion. The zombie appears as a warning: objectify others at your own risk.

sections.heading: Our Animal Selves in the Mirror
sections.text:
Humans used to look in the mirror and see something like Big Foot, and so when we see Big Foot, we see our ancient selves, our animal selves. Wherever the stories and legends emerge, whatever their specifics, where they come from in us is our never-ending relationship with our animal nature, sometimes repressed, sometimes engaged, and always in contrast to what we are now: civilized.

We evolved from animals, but we want to believe we are civilized. This tension plays out in the stories of wild hairy men and our belief, or denial, of their existence. Figures like Big Foot or the Yeti do not just recur around the world and across our mythic landscape; we also dream and make movies about them. They are in our mind. Not so long ago, we were more animal than human, we still have these tendencies, and in the same way we repress our animal instincts to be civilized, civilization denies the existence of Big Foot.

sections.heading: The World's Oldest Sidekick
sections.text:
The archetypal essence of Big Foot and comparable figures is at least as old as the world's first epic, Gilgamesh, whose best friend and sidekick fit the core description: a wild, hairy man who lived in the forest. In this ancient source, we do not just find a stagnant creature, we find a character arc. Enkidu, the best friend and sidekick, becomes civilized. This shows us what Big Foot is in our minds: a pre-civilized animal-person.

Going back to the first epic, we see wild hairy men in the forest, and the ancient source reveals an arc for this character: to become civilized. On one level, it is about defining civilized consciousness by contrasting it with our animal nature. On another level, it is used to teach us not to believe in anything abnormal or undiscovered. From the Tibetan stories of the Himalayan Yeti to the North American Big Foot, from the epics of India that describe monkey people to hunters in the Caucasus who learn not to track the hairy mountain dwellers, we find stories about these comparable figures around the world.

sections.heading: The Myth of Knowing Everything
sections.text:
Essential to the Big Foot myth is that it is a myth, that anyone who believes it is crazy. And beneath this myth is another myth: that we know everything, that we have been everywhere, that there is no unknown. Big Foot hunters are drawn to the unexplored in search of the unknown, to forests and mountains, where still today we find new species. The Okapi, for example, was only just discovered, and as far as Big Foot hunters are concerned, it is not half as intelligent or capable of evasion.

One of the core qualities of the recurring Big Foot myth is that, from Tibet to North America, it is the indigenous people and the people in the country who believe it is true, not the civilized people in normal society. When we ask if a mythic creature is real, the question is a bit misframed. It is real in our imagination, and the reason it is real in our imagination is because something inside has found a way to co-exist with something outside.

sections.heading: Denial, Projection, and the Inner Animal
sections.text:
Denial of Big Foot is fuelled by the repression of our inner animal. Fascination with Big Foot is a fascination with our inner animal. And love of Big Foot is a love of our inner animal, which aligns with our understanding of what it was to be one with Eden and God before the fall. This is where we get images of Big Foot as possessing the mystical powers of Adam, our pre-fallen ancestor.

Mythologically, we do not just see animals as less civilized, we also see them as more connected. And so, in the myth of Big Foot, we do not just see an uncivilized monster, we also see a connected being, who in some cases has mystical powers. These powers are like those of Adam before the fall, lost to civilization. The mythic demonization of our animal nature separates us from the consciousness our animal nature is capable of, which is its most mystical nature, its most telepathic nature, its most spiritually powerful nature.

By now, what Big Foot is in our minds is a mixture of bear stories and hairy humans, our own shadows and repressed animal consciousnesses, our relationship with the myth of knowing everything. Myths help us understand our reality. On a social level, the myth of Big Foot teaches us to be normal and doubt the unknown. On a psychological level, it teaches us to repress and distinguish ourselves from our animal nature. On a cosmological level, it teaches us that our role in existence is not to be embedded in creation, but to observe it consciously.

bigfoot-and-yeti.overview: Humans used to look in the mirror and see something like Bigfoot — and so when we encounter these stories, we encounter our own ancient, animal selves. The tension between our evolutionary past and our civilized present plays out in stories of wild hairy figures found around the world, from Gilgamesh's Enkidu to the Himalayan Yeti. The denial of Bigfoot is fueled by the repression of our inner animal, and the fascination is fueled by its return — the possibility that what we lost when we became civilized has not entirely disappeared.

sections.heading: Water, Waves, and the Way of Union
sections.text:
Life comes and goes with water, which behaves very differently than things. While two things cannot be in the same place at the same time, waves can, which is why quests for enlightenment and union are often quests for elixirs. When we see waves in the world we see the capacity for union.

A drop of water is one with the ocean. A grain of sand is apart from the desert. Waves and water do not behave like things on land. To cross or dive under the waves is not just a journey into the unknown; it is into a world that can teach us the way of resonance, of likeness, of union. These are the ways of dream, metaphor and myth. The drop becomes the sea in mystical poetry about union. A single coned speaker plays a single wave, in which we hear every instrument. To be at sea, or underwater, is to be in another world.

sections.heading: Ambassadors of the Unknown
sections.text:
We fear the disasters that come from the ocean, and in an effort to make them predictable, we personify the ocean's will. Typically, a sailor already has some notion of sea monsters, which are ready projections when things go awry. These monsters are ambassadors of the unknown. For someone this might mean a demon, or it might mean a god. We want to believe in an other, which must come from an other place. Before the focus on aliens, we saw otherness in the sea.

Myths are often born when the real world gives us a mirror for what might otherwise remain in our dreams. The more we want to believe in our dreams, the more likely we are to find them. When a clergyman sees a leviathan, it confirms the reality of the world they want to live in. The natural material world is always in co-creation with our mythic imagination. When some inner configuration finds its mirror in the outer world, when it finds a totem for its projection, that is when myths are born.

sections.heading: From Cetus to the Kraken
sections.text:
The earliest sea monster was the sea itself, all the storms and monsters it can bring. Very early in human history, we start to see this mythologized in the form of Cetus, the constellation of the great fish, which appears in the myths of Osiris, Perseus and Jonah. Leviathan has become synonymous with sea monster. It comes from the Bible and is comparable to the monsters slain by Zeus and Marduk when they built their world. These monsters were often conglomerate creatures, serpents, crocodiles, whales and squid, which represents their unbound nature. To defeat the sea monster is to forge order from chaos.

Architeuthis, the giant squid, is a myth-making machine, a mirror for our fears of the monstrous unknown. A good myth comes about when something literal and real triggers something imaginal and profound. When a pattern important to the psyche finds a mirror in the real world, myths happen, and still do. Scylla, the sea monster Homer describes in the Odyssey, is very likely the giant squid.

sections.heading: The Night Sea Journey
sections.text:
Our origins were nurtured by water of womb and sea. This is mythologized in the form of sunken cities and the ancient claim we evolved from fish. We see ocean life as older, and when we see water as vitality and origin, we see the Hebrew Tehom and the Egyptian Nu, oceans of chaos and creation. The ocean is a place of transformation. When a character is swallowed by the sea at sunset and returns with sunrise, they return reborn, as though from a womb.

When a hero is swallowed by a monster into the sea, it is often associated with the sunset. The return, conversely, is seen in the sunrise. It is at the bottom of the ocean, in the middle of the night, that fire must be stolen. From Hercules to Pinocchio, the fire they encounter in the belly of the whale is what turns the night sea journey into an ascent towards day.

sea-monsters.overview: Life comes and goes with water, which behaves differently than things on land — waves can occupy the same space, which is why quests for union are often quests for elixirs. Sea monsters are ambassadors of the unknown, personifications of the ocean's will born when the real world mirrors what lives in our dreams. From Scylla to the Kraken, from Cetus to Leviathan, the defeat of the sea monster is the forging of order from chaos — and the ocean remains the place where our oldest myths are most alive.

sections.heading: Trauma, Memory, and Mythic Layering
sections.text:
Mothman is one of those myths based on a major traumatic event that involved 46 deaths and multiple reports of paranormal activity. This is the stuff that becomes hard for a culture to forget. And like most historical memories, it has become layered with mythic content.

There is something interesting about the way this particular story avoids the recognizable mythic trappings that lead others to dismissal. There is something about how secular it feels as an event, paranormal but secular. The Mothman is not easily identifiable as anything that has already been dismissed: aliens, demons, reptilian illuminati. The lack of identifiable detail enables people to project their own possibilities into the narrative, which range from quantum speculations about the timelessness of soul to mundane dismissals of statistical anomalies.

sections.heading: American Folklore as Melting Pot
sections.text:
American folklore is a melting pot of traditions brought over from Europe and Africa, sometimes even Asia, to a crucible that was already cooking with native narratives and ancient memories. This American imagination was then responsible for the transmutation of our democratic, capitalistic, scientific and technological revolutions into mythopoeic dreams.

Native American folklore expresses a particularly shamanic quality in its recurring focus on the spirit world. That tricksters are more common than heroes is resonant with the prominence of shamanism over priesthoods and more orthodox religions. The Christian belief in the Fall leaves a back door for so-called primitive cultures to be seen by Christians as less fallen and more in touch with pre-scientific powers. At the same time, the Christian perception of the unconverted could lead to the conflation of shamans as witch doctors, if not devils. Both predispositions set up a projection of supernatural powers onto Native Americans.

sections.heading: The Curse of Chief Cornstalk
sections.text:
As the story goes, Chief Colesqua, also known as Chief Cornstalk of the Shawnee nation, pursued peace with Europeans until he and his son were shot dead. The story is that, as he died, he cursed his assailants and their entire culture. His remains were then moved, multiple times, to Point Pleasant, which is believed to have been haunted by the Mothman. The curse of a dying foe is an old motif that is taken very seriously, for the same reason prophecies depend on living entrails. The notion is that something between life and death can communicate truth, if not power, from one to another.

The curse would not be so scary if the so-called White Man did not actually know that what they had done was wrong, that a curse or retribution was right. And so, when something really happened, it would have been hard for anyone not to see a connection.

sections.heading: Cold War Paranoia and Winged Beings
sections.text:
We see through our lens that is ourselves. Paranoia leads to projection, and the 1960s were a time of paranoia. The Nazi use of state propaganda and the American use of a nuclear bomb were not yet distant memories. Cold War espionage was very real and intense. New scientific breakthroughs were only beginning to be understood. As the rise of secularism left a hole in the existential spirits of populations, they transferred their projections from religious figures, like angels and demons, to the more scientifically oriented aliens and paranormal research.

Birds represent an ability to traverse multiple domains, especially water birds that can dive below waves as well as fly above them. This has led to their association with the soul, which can hopefully travel between worlds. The Mothman, similarly, is seen as a being that straddles realities. The moth, like a butterfly, has transformed from a more primitive form. This relates to the belief of some that Mothmen are what we see when we look at our future incarnations. Interesting that it is not a butterfly but a moth, whose association with night can be conflated with an association with death. Both are symbolic of resurrection, but where the butterfly resurrects into day, the moth remains in night.

sections.heading: Where Myths Are Born
sections.text:
The weird stuff in myth is always projected onto locations beyond reach or rarely visited. Myths that spring up around mountains, seas, bottomless lakes and other unknown zones are typically more laden with the paranormal. In the same way it is easier to believe in ghosts when you are alone in a dark unknown place, darker, less known and less populated areas tend to be more able to sustain paranormal stories. The Appalachians seem to be an epicenter of urban legends and folklore in the United States.

Myths are the biggest stories most deeply engaged by the most people for the longest time. Myths are vessels made for wisdom, vehicles made for its carriage across distances and across time. Myths, like dreams, are the translation of mental activity into sensory experience. Too many people want to flatten myths into allegories, as though they can be reduced to a single inspiration. Myths emerge where patterns converge. In myth, something's pattern drags in the meaning of everything else with that pattern. And through pattern, myth mixes the human with nature, with animals, with the heavens.

mothman.overview: Mothman is one of those myths that avoids the recognizable trappings leading others to dismissal — not quite alien, not quite demon, not quite anything already categorized. Born from a real traumatic event involving forty-six deaths and layered with Cold War paranoia, Native American curses, and Appalachian folklore, it exists in a space where the secular and the paranormal refuse to separate. The lack of identifiable detail is precisely what makes the myth so durable — it lets everyone project their own possibilities into the narrative.

sections.heading: The Scourge of God and Shadow of Empire
sections.text:
Attila was the key figure in bringing down the Roman Empire, and he is a crucial nemesis in the epic cycle of Nibelung, which climaxes around the death of Attila and the loss of treasure to the Rhine. The longer and harder you hold something down, the more violently it will surface. This happened to the Romans in the form of Hun and Visigoth raids. Both were symptomatic of the same oppression, but where the Visigoths seem more like rebels seeking rights, the Huns seem more like terrorists seeking revenge.

Given all the shooters and terrorists in our world, this is something we should all be thinking about. Oppression leads to terrorism and rebellion. The question is whether we should be focused on Attila as the destroyer of civilization or as its shadow incarnate.

sections.heading: The Mounted Archer and the Fear of the Unknown
sections.text:
The real advantage of the Huns was their mounted archer, a motif that goes back to the centaur, which was likely inspired by the Huns' Indo-European ancestors. If the stories are to be believed, they were so fluid on their horses, it might as well have been part of their body. Their swift maneuvering also reduced the efficacy of opposing archers. Have you ever seen a sports match where one team is just faster than the others? That was the Huns, running plays and running circles around their enemies.

We always fear what we do not understand, especially when it can sneak up on you so quickly and wants you dead. Not only were the Huns somewhat foreign and beyond understanding; their mobility on horses and their prowess as archers must have had everyone everywhere on edge. This was a people that left wakes of carnage and intentionally spread fear, a people that cut themselves to mourn and faced battle fearlessly. Because anything someone cannot do or understand becomes quickly associated with magic, the Hun arrows of mounted archers, which could sneak up and kill you at a distance, would have been seen as almost magical.

sections.heading: Lost Graves, Lost Swords, and the Fantasy of Return
sections.text:
Arthur and Attila, great leaders of their people, were lost upon death. According to the Arthurian tradition, he was taken to the isle of apples, Avalon, from which the King will return. On one level, the lack of a grave or body permits the fantasy of return or resurrection among their followers. Great kings are typically buried with great treasure, for which reason the lost grave of a king becomes a myth of lost treasure.

Whether or not Attila is buried in a river, it is especially interesting that his sword would be, as the return of a king's magical sword to water is an ancient Indo-European motif seen in Arthur and Batraz. This is why we find swords in rivers. The Sword of Mars is not unlike the sword of Siegfried, Charlemagne or Arthur, all of which represented great might. It was given to Attila by a shepherd who found it in the grass. Symbolically, this may be a memory of the shepherd as the ancient patron of the pastoral Indo-Europeans and a recognition of the sword as a harvester of souls.

sections.heading: The Devouring Father and Mythic Memory
sections.text:
Attila, Atli, Etzel: these are likely just the translations of his name, "little father," into different languages and dialects. His name shares a prefix with Atlas, an Indo-European war-leader of the Titans. Insofar as the Romans sided with Olympus, you might say that the Titans, and all the raw drives they represented, finally won.

The scene of Attila eating his children in the Nibelung, intentional or not, aligns him with the mythic figure of the devouring father, most famously Cronus, who ate his children to resist their power and retain his own. The devouring of the son is the ultimate expression of the patriarchal tyrant that hoards power. In the Eddas, Atli's death is caused by his wife, which is true to history; but motifs that can be identified with older myths are introduced. We first think of Medea, a witch of the Caucasus who, like Gudrun, killed the children she bore to her husband. And like Gudrun, who sent the hair of a wolf, Medea's witchcraft, learned from Hekate, was associated with the wolf. This is an old Indo-European association of the mother and dog that can be seen in Satanaya as well as the wolf who suckled Romulus and Remus.

attila.overview: Attila was the shadow of empire incarnate — the figure who brought down Rome, representing what happens when oppression is held down long enough to surface as terror. His story converges with the Nibelung cycle, lost treasure in a river, and the ancient Indo-European motif of a king's sword returning to water. Whether we focus on Attila as the destroyer of civilization or as its shadow is a question that remains urgent in a world still producing the conditions that create such figures.

sections.heading: The Mystery That Won't Settle
sections.text:
Luckily, the meteor did not explode over an urban area; it was remote. That having been said, it was also the case that locals were so affected and superstitious about it that talking about it was not encouraged. The level of consensus required to really move on has not been reached, 110 years later. And we have not changed. We are still drawn to the unexplained with every possibility we want to explore.

Truth be told, the lack of a crater can be explained by a meteor's explosion in the atmosphere. It is even possible that an exploding meteorite could have caused such destruction. The real mystery is the strength of its shockwave, which should not have been generated by an exploding meteor, even a big one.

sections.heading: Tesla, UFOs, and the Open Bet
sections.text:
The story brings in Tesla, a mythic figure on his own. The theory is that Tunguska was produced by the death ray he claims to have been working on at the time. According to his account, he accelerated particles from the ionosphere with the help of a Tesla coil. This is a guy who invented the remote control and what seems like half of the world's technology while claiming to be in conversation with Martians. I find I never know what to believe when it comes to this guy, but I do know that he would have had a hard time creating the vacuum tube he should have needed to accelerate particles from the ionosphere. Then again, who am I to question Tesla?

If you cannot explain something completely, all bets are off. And when you are talking about a ball of fire from the sky, UFOs are going to be an obvious explanation. Some might point to the discovery of meteorite shards, but if our fighter jets use camouflage and drop flares, why would we not think UFOs drop meteorites when they have to self-destruct to preserve the prime directive? Most scientific reductions are worlds away from the scientifically possible.

sections.heading: The Realest Fear
sections.text:
There have been many recorded examples of meteorites that explode when hitting thicker layers of the atmosphere, which is the story of what happened at Tunguska. There are also accounts throughout history of fireballs and strange phenomena in the sky.

The realest fear is that this is what it looks like when a very big meteor luckily explodes just before impact. If a meteor this big had hit the earth, the damage would have been overwhelming. And we all know extinction events like this can occur.

tunguska.overview: Tunguska is the mystery that will not settle. Over a century later, the level of consensus required to move on has not been reached — and the event carries our realest fear, that this is what it looks like when a very large meteor barely misses devastating impact. The absence of a crater, the strength of the shockwave, and the remoteness of the site have left just enough unexplained to sustain every theory from Tesla's death ray to UFOs, because when something cannot be completely explained, all bets are off.
